lines: O: Certainly, Mr Roberts.
If you would like to ask a question at this time please press the star or asterisk key followed by the digit one on your telephone.
Please insure that the mute function on your telephone is switched off to allow your signal to reach our equipment.
If you find that your question has already been answered, you may remove yourself from the queue by pressing star-two.
Again please press star-one to ask a question and we pause for a moment to allow everyone to signal.
And we'll take our first question from Emmanuel Carlier from ING Bank.
Please go ahead.
Q: Hi.
Good afternoon.
Two questions from my side.
The first one is on the international business, so there I see that you increased the utilized transponders by 10%.
You also mentioned that the prices were stable year-over-year.
But still at fixed - at constant exchange rates I mean, the top line increased by only 5%.
So, could you maybe clarify that a little bit?
And then, secondly, on the order backlog, you do not really quantify that this year while usually you do so.
Could you maybe update us there on the number?
Thank you.
A: Yeah.
Emmanuel, on the second question about the order backlog
A: 7.3 billion.
A: It's in the document, not - it's not in the document.
It's 7.3 million.
A: Billion, billion, yeah.
A: Yeah, 7.3 billion.
Sorry.
So, it's basically slightly below the 7.5 billion we reported at year end.
But those are really the elements related to timing when contracts close.
So, for example, the contracts that we have not yet announced the customer call but we announced the contract for DTH in Eastern Europe has been signed in April this year.
So, contracts like these are not yet included in the Q1 number.
So, don't pay too much attention about small variations of the backlog number.
It's more or less at the same level as it was at the end of the year.
And, Padraig, on the first question?
A: Yep.
And so, on the first question, Emmanuel, just dealing with the international revenue development, I guess, two aspects to it.

So, first of all, in terms of the aspect of looking at the utilization growth versus the overall revenues utilization, so if we look at the first quarter, for example, compared to last quarter 2012 where you see utilization of 16 transponders, the first point is that we have a sequential revenue reduction in quarter one versus quarter four at constant FX of about 4.5 million, which is mainly driven by the seasonality of services in quarter four of the calendar year and related then with sales.
If we exclude this seasonality, revenue is slightly up, partially reflecting the increase in utilization.
On your specific point on the mix between volume and price, most of the 16 transponders have been contracted late in the quarter and didn't contribute much to revenue in quarter one 2013.

And thirdly, we have, I would say, a specific customer-related issue in quarter one, and that is with TopTV in South Africa who is in business restructuring and for whom we have not recognized revenue in quarter one 2013.
This customer has 3 transponders with us.
However, we continue to service and assume to generate revenue as of the date that the company has restructured.
And I think, if you're following the press on this, you will see that there are positive developments coming in this area.
So, overall, we can confirm that prices are remaining relatively stable but we do have a couple of these points which create this outcome.
Q: Okay.
That's very clear.
Thank you.
O: We'll take our next question from David Cerdan from Kepler.
Please go ahead.
Q: Yeah.
Good afternoon, gentlemen.
I have a couple - several question.
The first question I have is regarding your - the business you have with the US DoD.
You seem not to be impacted by the sequestration.
I would like just to know how is it possible, because your main competitors reported some poor numbers with this client.
And my second question is regarding depreciation.
You should launch a lot of satellite in - from this quarter.
So, at which extent do you expect the depreciation to increase in Q2 versus Q1?
And my third question is regarding the potential impact, if there is some delays roughly by one quarter for the new satellite, at which extent this will impact or could impact your business plan?
Thank you.
A: Yeah, David, maybe I'll take your first, and the second question, I would ask Padraig to take the second one on depreciation.

So, regarding the US government business, so we are all operating, obviously, in the same market and so, it might be surprising that different from our competitors, Eutelsat, Intelsat and then maybe to some extent also Inmarsat, we have not reported negative impact from the sequestration.
So, facts are that in the first quarter 2013, as we state, we have solid results from the revenues coming from the US government.
We will, obviously, continue to monitor the situation.
The sequestration is a reality.
And so, obviously, if there were to be developments, we will report with the quarterly results.

But maybe one reason why we feel somewhat maybe more protected than maybe some of our competitors is the fact that, first, the percentage of revenues in our numbers coming from the government - US government is probably below what it is for our competitors.
And then, second, we have - it's 10%.
And then, second, within these revenues, there is a quite healthy mix between customers.

So, we have civil customers, meaning departments who are working like, at least like agriculture, like education, like health, the departments which have nothing to do really with defense, where most of the sequestration impacts are felt.
And second, when it comes to the defense or protection activities, there also we have a quite nice mix from the geographic perspective.
We have a lot of revenues being generated with the US government for coverage of North America - over North America.
So, nothing to do really with conflicts in different regions of the world.

Or maybe last way to describe it, and you might remember this, years ago, when our competitors took advantage of the fact that there was a huge demand of capacity from the US government in the Middle East, in Afghanistan, in Iraq, we said that we had no capacity available to serve the US government.
And so, at the time, we did not profit of that opportunity.
So now, if the opportunity were to come to an end or were to decrease, obviously, it's normal that we would not suffer from this because we did not profit from it years ago.

On the third question, which is about the potential impact of launch delays, as I said, with the delays that we know so far compared to what we knew at the time when we guided early in the year, this is still manageable within the guidance range that we shared with you.
Obviously, if there were to be further delays, clearly, then we would have to reconsider the conclusion.
We will report about this.
We will identify the impact of the delays and we will clearly share that information with you.
And needless to say, as I said before, that more than half of the capacity that we will launch mainly on SES-6 and on SES-8 are contracted.
So, clearly, launch delays would have a substantial impact because these satellites basically will generate quite a lot of revenues as of day one when they enter into service.
Q: And
A: Again
Q: And is there...
A: Yes, please?
Q: Yeah.
Just to finish on this point, if there is a delay, do you estimate that you will receive some compensation?
A: Well, no, not really.
Maybe slight - no, not really.
And let's also be very clear, the risk is, today, not very high because the next satellite to be launched on Proton is SES-6.
And as I said, ASTRA 2E is a follow-up launch for ILS.
So, when we exclude the Russian launch of GLONASS, the next ILS launch after SES-6 is not SES launch, ASTRA 2E.
So, we are the next on the launchpad so - and then it seems things are obviously progressing.
So, satellites are already fueled, and I was thinking by [indiscernible] .
On SES-8, that's the second Falcon launch, and there is a Canadian satellite ahead of us, which is scheduled to be launched in July, and then our satellite should be launched in August.
And finally, the fifth satellite - the fourth satellite, which is ASTRA 5B, this satellite is expected to be launched in the September-October timeframe on the Ariane launch vehicle.
And there, as well, I believe there's only one Ariane launch ahead of us.
So, there is not really a high risk regarding more delays.
So, satellites, by the way, are ready for launch.

So, the delay can only come with the availability of the launch vehicles because the satellites, some of them are already on the launch site, and others are basically ready to be shipped to the launch site.
Q: Okay.
Thank you.

A: And David, on the depreciation, so it is correct that as we launch new satellites and bring them into service, and typically, you can allow a period of, it varies, but a period of six weeks, sometimes eight weeks, to come to customer service date.
So, the depreciation will increase for those.
But just as satellites go into service, satellites also come out of service.
And for example, you see that we have in Q3 ASRTA 2E and we have in Q1 of next year ASTRA 2D.
So, these are replacing two existing satellites already at 28.2 million where normally these satellites would be coming to the end of their depreciation lives.
We have other satellites that would also be coming to the end of their lives.

And I think a good example is just looking at the first quarter results where we had the start of service - of operations of SES-4, SES-5, ASTRA 2F, but we had the end of depreciation for 1G, 1H, 2D and 3A.
So, overall, we think that the guidance range of 480 million to 520 million is taking into account the new satellites coming in and the satellites which become fully depreciated.
Q: Okay.
Thank you very much.
A: Take the next question, please, Regina.
O: We'll take our next question from Mark Walker from Goldman Sachs.
Please go ahead.
Q: Hi, everybody.
I have three questions, please.
The first one is about the SES Broadband Services business.
I just wonder if you can talk a bit more about the opportunity there, what are the key markets for that product and to what extent could that contribute to your mid-term revenue growth outlook?
And also more near-term, should we expect a margin drive from marketing around that service?

Secondly, I wonder if you could give a bit more color around the traction on your HD+ product and, specifically, whether we should think about potential price increases going forward in that product, whether the sort of 50 flat fee is something we should hold in our models.
And the third question is around O3b.

Given the imminent launch of satellites in June and then September, I wonder if you could update us on the financial expectations for that business, specifically whether you continue to expect around $40 million of revenues per satellite with the fleet of 20 satellites.
And also, give us an idea of the timing needed to ramp up to that level.
Likewise, how long should it take for the margins in that business to reach the FSS industry averages?
Thank you.
A: Okay.
So, maybe, Mark, I'll start with your last question first and not to say a lot because I think we can simply refer to the data and the guidance that we have given in the past.
And obviously, there is no reason for us to update this because we are still ahead of, or before the launch and so since what we explained already, I would say, a year or a year-and-a-half ago.
Maybe simply one comment on the precise question you said about ramp-up, that's simply depending on the way capacity will be commercialized.
Don't forget that different from most of the geostationary satellites, O3b is a satellite constellation with 10 beams per satellite.
So, with 8 satellites, there are 80 beams, with 12 satellites, there are 120 beams.
And the ramp-up basically depends on whether in one beam, you find an anchor customer who is taking all of the bandwidth in one contract.
And then, obviously, the ramp-up in that beam is 100% as of the day of service start.
But if the customer is only taking, let's say, 50% of the bandwidth, then you have to fix - to freeze the beam.

Let's say, if it is Cook Islands Telecom, then you freeze the beam over the Cook Islands and then O3b has to find the customers either Cook Telecom in further beams or other customers to take the remainder of the bandwidth.
So, it's difficult to give you a standard answer there.
It's really depending on whether the customer is taking the full beam or whether the customer is only taking part of the beam.
But I think, Mark, if I remember correctly, we always guided to a ramp-up here at an average of two to three years for these satellites.
A: Yeah.
That's correct.
With the constellation beams [indiscernible] .
A: Yeah.
So, but for the rest, please really refer to the information we have conveyed in the past because there's no reason - no update required on that one.
HD+, we are not planning for any price increase for the time being.
I think it's good to have HD+ continuing to grow its business, and the number of TV channels available are 15.
Maybe there is one new channel I've seen that might have been added, MTV, but basically, the program lineup is what it is.
I think it's good marketing and a good commercial approach not to think about price increase at the time where we are still acquiring and continue to acquire the new paying households for HD+.
On your first point about Broadband Services, maybe I'll start with the first comment, that's really to play down the importance of SBBS, so, meaning, our Broadband Services.
You know that's different from some of our competitors.
We have not invested in any dedicated satellite capacity for residential broadband in Europe.
So, we have added Ka-band payloads on Ku-band satellites that we had to launch anyway in order to replace satellites for direct-to-home television.

And with an investment - small incremental investment of less than 10 million per satellite, we have added broadband or Ka-band capabilities for residential broadband services of - and that's my second point - of the same quality of what competitors are able to offer.
So, we are very competitive in the market.
We are also offering speeds up to 20 megabits per second in the regions that are covered by our incremental payloads and by our beams that we have on those satellites.

And so, I am quite confident that we will able to really have a nice development of that business, which is limited in scope and also limited in times of exposure - in terms of exposure that we have when compared to the competition.
So, and we have launched early in the year the service in Ka-band, I think, in France, in the UK, and I think we will launch it later in the year in the German-speaking countries.
A: It's already available.
A: It's already available in the German-speaking countries.
So, basically you can say our market for broadband services in Europe is essentially the French-speaking countries, the German-speaking countries and the UK.
Q: That's all really clear.
Thank you very much.
A: Thank you.
O: And we'll take our next question from Francisco Sanches from Credit Suisse.
Please go ahead.
Q: Hi.
Good afternoon.
Thanks for taking my question.
Just if you could share with us any details on any capacity coming from the SES-6 satellite or any capacity coming from the LatAm region which you might have already presold?
A: Yeah.

Obviously, Francisco, we would be pleased to do so but we have signed a contract with a customer who has asked us not to disclose this for competition reasons, meaning, to keep a competitive edge over their competitors.
And so, we have to respect this wish of the customer.

But I would say, you have to be patient, but I would guess, at the latest when the satellite will be launched, the customer will have to accept that we are communicating on the identity of the customer.
So, I would say, maybe we give you rendezvous on June 3 in case of the satellite transponders .
Q: Right.

If I may, just one more question on - and sorry to keep bringing the subject on the US government issue, is there any reason linked to the length of your contracts with the DoD that might be the reason for you not having any impact on the DoD in this quarter, i.e., I guess what I'm trying to ask is if the length of your contract, if it is greater than six months like, for example, your competitors, so that might suggest why you didn't suffer anything at this time but might suggest also that some impacts could still to come - could still be to come?
A: No, no, no.
That's not at all the case.
The length of these contracts, the standard length is one year because of the annual budget.
And so, obviously, the contracts start at different times of the year.
But the typical length of a contract is 12 months and so we don't have such an impact.
Note that that's what I said .
The main reason is really that we have a very diversified customer base when you look at the government and institutions, even within the US government.

And number two is that when you look more at the DoD or the different activities, the national protection and security, we have a quite nice balance of the revenues between North America and the other regions of the world, which definitely is not the case for some of our competitors.
Q: Okay.
Thank you very much.
A: Thank you.
A: And we have another question, Regina?
O: Yes.
We'll take our next question from Giles Thorne from Jefferies.
Please go ahead.
Q: Hi, there.
Thanks for taking my questions.
I have three, please.
Still on the sequester, there's obviously been a lot of focus on US DoD business, but the legislation says that half the cuts come from defense and half the cuts come from non-defense.

So, I take your point that it's nice to have a diversified mix and you've got lots of homeland applications over North America, but surely there will come a point when you will start to feel the pinch.
So, I'd just be interested to hear your confidence - hear you comment on that.

And in addition, if I look at the 10% of group revenue that you have from the US government as the end customer, what percentage currently - what percentage of that currently sits within protected budgets?
Second question was, actually, a follow-up on the launch delay.
If I understand right, both ASTRA 2E and SES-6 are ILS launches and ASTRA 2E was always scheduled to be before SES-6.
So, the fact that has now been pushed back but SES-6 is still on track suggests to me that it's an issue with your manufacturing partner rather than your launch partner.
So, given that Eutelsat in its very last results reported a healthy revenue number from the late delivery of satellites under procurement, how come you're not receiving the same?
And lastly, on O3b, we're very close to the first launch now and you've reported another, what seems to be, a healthy increase in the revenue pipeline there.

I'd just be interested to hear your thoughts on when you cast your mind back when you originally put money into this venture compared to how the commercial traction is coming through to date, is it tracking better than you originally expected, in line with how you expected or behind your original expectations?
Thank you.
A: Yeah.
Giles, maybe to start and then not to be too long on your last point because, I guess, colleagues of yours would also want to still ask some questions.
O3b, that can be a discussion also at the Investor Day I would refer to.

But maybe to say it in one or two sentences, I believe what has completely changed really when we look at O3b is that we saw that when we did the investment, this was for some applications like trunking, maybe some mobile backhauling activities.

And what has developed over the years is really a very nice set of different applications targeting different verticals, different market segments, and really showing that the potential of O3b is going far beyond what we saw at the time of the investment.
We were always convinced about the solution, about the advantage of the solution, high-speed, low latency, large bandwidth, flexibility in the coverage area.

But what really the team also under Steve Collar's leadership have really nicely developed these really - products that are so attractive to different market segments that I would definitely say it is going well beyond our expectation.
On the second point regarding launch, delays and the question of this what ASTRA 2E and SES-6, there's no problem with satellite manufacturer because it's the same.
So, basically, the two satellites have been built by EADS Astrium, and we asked them and we asked also ILS to swap the satellites and to launch SES-6 first, and then only to launch ASTRA 2E.

So, reason is that, yeah, we have a large customer for SES-6, and we will announce it in due time, whereas ASTRA 2E is mainly replacement capacity, not only but mainly replacement capacity for Europe and overseas.
We have more time there to replace the ASTRA 2 satellites there.
And this satellite is generating less revenues - less incremental revenues compared to SES-6.
So, that's why we asked the manufacturer and the launch vehicle service provider to turn things around.
On the government, your first question, I'm confident - I would simply say one word.
Yes, definitely, there will be an impact of the sequestration on the demand for satellite capacity coming from the US government over time.
So, a short-term negative impact is normal.
But, and that's much more important, I would say, I expect a very positive mid-term and long-term impact resulting from this sequestration.

That's really the use of satellite from commercial - of capacity from commercial satellite operators versus the government spending hundred of millions and billions of dollars to invest in their own satellite.
So, I believe that the budget situation will lead to more of the capacity being - capacity requirement being covered by commercial satellite operators.
And so that should be a very good outlook for us and also for our competitors, by the way.
Q: Thank you.
Just a quick follow-up, could you give us - so, can you give us a bit of a stir on how much of your government revenue sits within protected budgets?
A: No, we are not giving any detail on - information on any single customer.
Q: Understood.
That's very helpful.
Thanks.
A: Thank you.
O: We'll take our next question from Nick Dempsey from Barclays.
Please go ahead.
Q: Yeah.
Good afternoon.
Two questions, please.
The first one, I remember in North America last year, you had a boost in the third quarter.
So, you've got tough comps out.

I was wondering if you can give us any color on how equipment sales have been going in North America and basically, whether we should be modeling a decline in North America in the second half due to that tough comp or that could be offset by something else.

And the second point, can you remind us how many former analogue transponders in Germany you've re-contracted in principle but which are not yet contributing to your revenues and when those will kick in?
A: I'll take your second question, Nick.
First, that's very simple, and I think I called out in principle.
We have re-contracted certain transponders and they are all generating revenues as of January this year.
And so - and we have a pipeline of additional opportunities on 19.2.
But, obviously, we will only report about service branded contracts that have been signed.
A: Sorry.
There is someone on the line who is not on mute.
So, I don't know, please - because that's a little bit disturbing on the line.
Thank you.
A: Padraig, please.
A: Yep.
And so, on the second question, Nick, I believe the amount you're referring to was an amount that we account for in the third quarter.
At the time we explained that that was something which was in our full-year revenue for last year.
But the revenue recognition was such that it fell in the third quarter.
Overall, it's - we're not - let's say, including right now, we don't foresee right now a large deal such as that.
So, you would be correct to say that normally there should be some downward movement in North America.
Having said that, the nature of some of these contracts are such that you really can't predict them and, in particular, the nature of equipment is as such that you can't predict them.
And typically, we've always tended to have a step-up particularly in those types of deals more to the next quarter.
Q: Thank you.
That's clear.
A: I think we've got time for one more question, Regina.
O: And we'll take our next question from Mathieu Robilliard from BNP Paribas.
Please go ahead.
Q: Yes, good afternoon.
Thank you very much.
Two very quick questions.
First, the 6 transponders that you contracted in April in Europe, can you tell us on which position they are?

And second, just on O3b, could you maybe give us an indication, I mean, maybe even if it's not definite but kind of a range of what the equipment price will be for O3b for your customers or your resellers on the ground?
Thank you.
A: Mathieu, honestly, I can't answer the second question, I don't know.
I don't know whether we could share that information with you, but I don't know.
And don't forget there is a quite large range of equipment and the size of terminal is quite different, number one.
Number two is the terminals and the sophistication of the terminals is also quite different application-to-application.
For example, maritime is obviously a much more sophisticated terminal than if you use it for trunking, for example.
So, that's why I believe that's a very difficult question.
And don't forget, to avoid any misunderstanding, this is a B2B business.
So, this has obviously nothing to do with residential or for residential broadband.
All of this is really for telcos, for satellite service providers, for - we are called service providers, for example, providing services to the cruise company.
If I take the example of the Royal Caribbean, some of the cruise ships, that's offered by CapRock Harris because that had been announced.
So, it's really professional service providers that will use the O3b equipment.
On the first question regarding the 6 transponders, I think I said it before but maybe it was a little bit too short.
This is for 31.5 degree East.

So, it's a customer rolling out direct-to-home in Central and Eastern European countries and using our 31.5 degree East orbital position where, during the year, we will add additional capacity with the launch of ASTRA 5B.
Q: All right.
Thank you very much.
Mark Roberts: Okay.
Thank you very much for joining us today, everybody.
And we remain on our usual contact numbers if you should require any further information.
Thank you.
O: That will conclude today's conference call.
Thank you for your participation, ladies and gentlemen.
You may now disconnect.
O: Thank you.
If you would like to ask a question please press the star-one on your telephone keypad.
Please insure the mute function on your telephone is switched off to allow your signal to reach our equipment.
If you find that your question has already been answered, you may remove yourself from the queue by pressing star-two.
Again please press star-one to ask a question.
We'll take the first question from Paul Sidney from Credit Suisse.
Q: Thank you very much.
Just two quick questions, please.
First question on Ultra HD.
You said three months ago that you expected a pickup in Ultra HD to be driven by big global events starting in 2016 with the Olympics, et cetera, but I just wondered.
Is there any interesting developments recently, especially in the run up to the World Cup in terms of testing, trialing, et cetera?

And just a second question; I was just wondering on your recently-won Brazilian slots, when will you be able to start utilizing those slots that you've acquired, either by relocating an existing satellite or launching a new satellite?
Thank you.
A: Thank you.
So let me start with the first question.
As you may have seen recently the announcement of the trial with Sky Germany on one of our satellites, I think this arena is taking shape.
There are probably three factors that we would need to see to make this development a reality within the 2016 runway, and it remains our belief that this is going to be sort of the inflection year.
One is that the majority of the content is effectively produced in 4K, which is the case.
Two is that the devices that are available in the marketplace are economically reachable.

What gives us confidence to say that is if we go back in time and look at the price point when HD was introduced, so I think year zero, and the evolution on that price point over the following years and where it is today and we try to draw a parallel with the price point of an Ultra HD.
What is quite interesting is to obverse that between April 2013 and April 2014, the average price of an Ultra HD screen has gone down anywhere between 36% and 41%.
And, in fact, that momentum of reduced prices may be moving faster than what we have seen with HD before.
And so we can expect that Ultra HD screen will become mainstream in the houses fairly quickly.
If my memory serves me well, recent studies show that two out of three consumers, when exposed to an experience of an Ultra HD screen, would say, yep, we want to buy that.
So there is a differentiation technically and sort of from a user experience.
The economics of the entry point on the device is getting there.

And so the third part I'm referring to in my earlier remark has to do with now the broadcasters are actually starting to move some of the content into that theme, and in a number of conversations with customers, this is more and more a central element of our discussions.
So we believe that these three elements are converging in the right direction and 2016 may well be the important inflection point for us.
Q: Thank you.
Sorry, just on the first point, did you say that you expected content by 2016 to generally be made in 4K?
A: Yeah.
A good deal of the content already produced today is produced in 4K, or you can use augmentation technologies that will give you a very good output.
If you want to use the color of the augmentation from SD to HD may not work as good as from HD to Ultra HD.
But nevertheless, if I put this aside, in terms of upstream producing the content in 4K, this is happening much faster than we had expected.
Q: Thank you.
A: Okay.
Now on Brazilian and just to clarify, so, effectively, earlier this week, it was announced that we won two slots, 48 West and 64 West.
On 48 West, where we provide the rights for C, Ku and Ka and FFS, we tend to do the following.
One is use these rights to serve our customers in Brazil with our assets 806 which is flying at 47.5 and C and Ku FSS as the secondary mission.
This will also allow us to expand our services in the Pan-Latin American market.
Last but not least, is to continue with the Pan-Latin American market antenna program.
And we may well develop as this progresses in Europe a satellite for starting a second C-band media neighborhood.
But our priority now is to use these new rights within the existing park of assets we have.

And that is the position that is offered to us with the large park of satellites that we have, and allows us to sort of pursue a number of these developments while mitigating a number of the - very significantly, the risk associated with having investments at the outset.
464 West which gives us the right of Ku/BSS, for us, it is going to be an opportunity to optimize delivery of DTH in Latin America.
And again, our starting point may well be an existing set of assets or an asset, and we already have a view how do we want to do that.
So I hope I've answered your question.
Q: That's extremely helpful.
Thank you.
O: We'll now take the next question from David Cerdan from Kepler.
Q: Yeah.
Good afternoon, gentlemen.
I have few questions if I may.
First of all, I would like to better understand your trend in Europe, which was quite good.
Could you split the revenue growth between the Eutelsat effect and HD+ effect?
My second question is regarding your cash return policy.
Do you expect to make some share buyback during 2014?
Or do you expect to invest in some new project, because if I'm right, around 50 million of CapEx could be dedicated in 2014 for a new CapEx?
And, third question, if I may, is regarding your HD channels.
If I'm right, Q, the end of last year, the number of channels was slightly higher than at the end of March.
So is there something special in this decline?
Thank you.
A: Yep.
So thank you.
On the first question with regard to Europe.

So, as I said earlier, due to the MDA between ourselves and Eutel, I can't give you the precise figures, but in order to help you there, what we can talk about is maybe, let's talk a little bit about the organic growth and in terms of what would have been driving that.
So, first of all, you recall last year, we had important capacity agreement signed in 2013, the second half of 2013.
Most notably, there was two transponders with Sky.
Also, in the first quarter of this year, we had a 19.2 transponder with ORF, the Austrian broadcaster.

We've also seen an important contribution in the first quarter results coming from the continued growth of HD+, which is now up to 1.5 million paying subscribers and SPS, Platform Services, are going quite well in addition.
So I think the best way maybe to look at it is to rather than look at Europe itself, is to look at the overall growth in the group.

And I think there, you should first of all - clearly, the first quarter has benefited from the Eutelsat transaction and so you shouldn't think now for the full year that this 8% is an uplift of our 6% to 8% guidance because there's clearly been a benefit on that.
And I think the way to look at it is if you refer back to my earlier revenue slide, if you take Europe and if you take International, you see that in itself was a 9.8% growth.
And then you saw the Americas coming down 1.8%.

And so, I think with that looking at the type of organic growth that I've outlined in Europe, understanding that the first quarter was benefiting from those sales, I think you should be able to get an idea on what the fit could have been.
On your second question, which relates to the cash return policy here, I think our policy on this remains consistent.
Our priorities for application of cash have always been, first of all, looking at, as you know, we have the progressive dividend policy which historically has been increasing at 10% a year.
And then we - next policy is to look at the profitable growth investments, the organic growth and also any inorganic growth, always looking at our investment hurdle rate.

In terms of your specific question, then we do consider other applications of funds in the context of an overall commitment to maintain our current investment-grade rating, and where we believe our optimized leverage is somewhere around 3.3 times.
You can take around 3 times at the end of the year, because it normally goes up in the second quarter with the dividend.
And if we satisfy these conditions together, there's the potential to consider share buyback for additional dividends.

But again, as we said last year on a number of occasions, share buyback of returning cash is not now a short-term objective for us as we believe we can deliver a better shareholder return in the short term by continuing with some of these growth opportunities which can deliver and which will deliver good IRR hurdle rates.
And what you have to look at then is the longer term, where we've said there's significant cash generation coming up, and clearly, share buyback is a part of the options there.
And last but not least, just to be aware that we do have, continuously every year in place, shareholder approval to do share buyback and that this approval is renewed annually.
So it's already an integral part of our approach, but it's not something that we would say is a top priority for 2014.
Q: Thank you.
And my last question regarding the HD channels?
A: HD+?
Q: No, it's regarding the HD channels, which was, if I'm right, slightly in decline?
A: No, no, no.
The...
Q: Not on the...
A: Our HD channels went up by 12%.
Q: No.
Yes, but not on a quarterly basis.
If you look at the number of HD channels at the end of 2013, it was...
A: Yep.

So I would like just to check that is there something special related to that or not?
A: No.
A: Yeah, we're not aware of the special one there, David.
We can check that and come back to bilaterally, but there's nothing special that I am aware of.

Where we're at today on the combination of the four, is we're in the mid-60s, so there's a prefill on that.

And I would say that that's something which we've seen now over a number of years and which is quite sustainable and developing nicely.
We also see in our TechCom business that we are contracting capacity outside of the ASTRA fleet and in other regions of the world linked to contracts that we're doing.
And then the last one which may move up and down a little bit is the US Government Services part.

Last year in the US Government Services, particularly in the first half of the year, we have certain contracts where we won larger contracts, but to win them, we had to move certain services all throughout the - onto other fleets and now we see part of that capacity and the reverse trend coming.
So that one on the Government Services, I think depends very much in the opportunities that are there.
And then the second one, which is the pull-through on the European Services is, I would say, a more continuing sustainable upward trend.
Q: So is, to some extent, the weakness in government that's impacted the US business is kind of partly negated by the eliminations coming down?

O: The next question will come from Eric Beaudet from Natixis.
Q: Yes, hello.
Two questions if I may.
The first one is regarding your verticals.
I noticed you mentioned the new market verticals quite a few time this year.

I was just wondering that before you can realize any revenues in these verticals, will you need some investment, a new sales force, new software platforms, the idea here being that usually when you get a new DTH contract, the top line falls pretty much directly on your EBITDA.
Can we see the same trend going on with these, now that you're targeting vertical markets or will these be dilutive on your EBITDA margin?
And my second questions regard your O3b fleet constellation.

You had mentioned that your first four satellites had encountered some technical problems and now, you mentioned this press release that you actually started service in the Pacific on these satellites.
So I was wondering are you satisfied now with the way they work or do you think they might need a replacement later on or any update on that would be perfect?
Thank you very much.
A: Sure.
So let me start with the first one.
When it comes to developing and serving new verticals, to a great extent, we're able to do that within our existing fleet.
We're also mindful that as we further grow - and we are already doing so.
So a case in point would be the aeronautical mobility vertical where we're already serving clients such as Panasonic, Google use RAW 54.
So this is capacity that is being used to provide supplied-based connectivity to airplanes seat-by-seat depending whether it's two-way or one-way connectivity.

And we are also mindful that as this market grows and our expectation that it will significantly grow because we're almost starting from a very small base, that part of our future fleet will be customized to serve this and to improve the user experience.
We don't expect in any way that this will be EBITDA dilutive.
On the contrary; we maintain the same investment thresholds that we're using with our core video market and no differentiation how we look from an investment go, no-go criteria.
So I hope in some way I've answered your question.

On O3b, the current operational space status is that now we have brought the operational protocol of satellites one to four to a level where they are performing ahead of the specs and that has been very positive news.

Clients where we started the trials have said, look, we haven't experienced anything like this kind of delivery and quality of delivery with prior experiences that we've had with supplied-type connectivities, which is very positive and this was our expectations going into the O3b investments.

This is not to say that - it took some time to optimize the protocol and also to make sure that there were operational fine tunings and technical fine tunings, we didn't have to go through a very significant learning curve specifically or to the management team.
So we have four satellites that are operational today.
The lifetime of the satellite may be impacted and the O3b CEO has made a statement to that effect.
What is not impacted is the quality of the performance of the satellite, since now, we have optimized the protocol.

Having said that, because this is a new fleet, with four satellites, we cannot serve on a continuous basis our client and therefore, the priority is to make sure that satellites five to eight are up and running.
We need a minimum of six satellites to make sure that the handover between the signal of one satellite and the other is done in a seamless manner and there is absolutely no interruption whatsoever.
In some parts of the world because of the topography we can do that, but that's the exception, that's not the rule.
And so, probably, what would be important is to state that with the June 2014 launch planned as such, O3b will be fully operational in August 2014.
Q: Thank you very much.
A: Thank you.

A: Good.
John, why don't you take the first question.
So, John Purvis, our Chief Legal Counsel and our chief leader on the WRC-15 topic is best qualified to shed some light on this.
A: Thanks for your question, Giles.
You're right, it's a very important question.

There's a lot of debate in the regulatory world leading up to the next WRC, next year in Geneva regarding, indeed, particularly focusing on the C-band and whether some of that should be allocated and shared with terrestrial services.

To some extent, it's a rerun of the debate leading up to the WRC-2007, which, as you may recall, the satellite industry, I think made a very good case for why there should be - remain a fixed allocation for satellite services.
So the industry is very active.
There's a very big campaign making sure that regulators around the world are understanding the need to preserve C-band for satellite.
For instance, this week we met with the Indonesian regulators and they're a very good example of understanding the importance in the markets for preserving C-band for satellite services.

So I think, obviously, no outcome can be guaranteed, but I think we remain cautiously confident that regulators will understand the need to preserve C-band for satellite services and not pursue these sharing arguments, which if you've read some of the reports, I think our view is that the IMT sector is - the way that they calculate the spectrum needs are exaggerated and not really a good data point for the discussion in Geneva next year.
Q: That's very clear.
A: So, let me take the second question, which I think relates to the recent auction in Brazil and let me start with the elimination.
The idea is that this spectrum we've acquired is not tradable.

We've acquired that spectrum to pursue either the strengthening of our existing business and/or to start developing new growth opportunities by again leveraging the large fleet of existing assets that we have that we can relocate.
Do we see a sustained potential there?

The answer is yes, provided we can do this in a differentiated manner and these trends we have had so far with our fleet and on the neighborhoods where we are present and where we're already generating very significant revenue deltas, yes, we can continue to do that.
But that is not a broad brush statement that says, in an open-ended manner, we continue to add capacity in Latin America; that is not the intent.
A: Yeah.
And maybe, Giles, then on your last question on Canal+ and the move to MPEG-4, I mean clearly, we see this as really a very strong case study.

It illustrates what we've been saying for some time which is that increased compression formats are actually a growth enabler and that it will permit more efficient use of capacity and better, higher quality.

You may recall that about two years ago, we did very large long-term renewals with Canal+ where I believe, I'm looking to colleagues, where I believe it was 24 transponders which included some additional transponders.

And clearly, what we see here is that - and we've seen this throughout the life of satellite broadcasting, is that whenever compression comes along, it's a growth enabler; it allows customers to do more higher quality content.
And you also see that with Canal+ themselves because actually, the number of HD channels that they've broadcast in the last two years have close to doubled.
So we see this as a very good case study where we're working with our customer and where the move to MPEG-4 gives us long-term renewals and additional capacity.
Q: So just an extension to that, can we extend that, your thinking there, to Project Ethan that's Sky's driving in the U.K.
or I think those new set-top boxes are going to be HDBC ready and your working model is that a launch of Ultra HD broadcast will just fill those operational efficiencies that they'll generate?
A: Well, I think here with - Sky is a highly valued customer of SES and together, we constantly introduce new innovations and enhancements to the customer offering.
We see this is as a continuation of this approach.

It's consistent with our view of the fact that increasing the hybrid solutions will enhance the advantage of satellite distribution, which continues to be the best mechanism for delivering point-to-point high quality of service and highly economical.
And it's not in a way inconsistent with developments we're doing in other markets.

You know about our satellite P project, you know about our satellite LNB project whereby we see satellite as a very attractive complement situation for any hybrid solution and that any hybrid solution actually enhances the value of satellite.
A: And to your point with the acceleration of the advent of ultra-high definition, the central role of satellite will be strengthened.
So it's important for us again as SES to play a very significant role in shaping that ecosystem and Project Ethan is part of that ecosystem.
Q: Very clear.
Thank you, very much.

That's again, just to remind, to go back to the basics, it's because it's a smaller percentage.
Government business is a smaller percentage of total business.
It's quite a diversified portfolio across different services.

When they were major growth jumps a number of years ago, say with entire assets being deployed in areas of conflict, this was not a benefit for SES and therefore, we did not get a penalty on that one.
As the year progressed and as we came into the second half of the year, we then saw the first impact with contracts which were coming up not being renewed.

And so what you actually see now in the first quarter results is you have to position it against quite a high comparable last year, where we hadn't really, at that point of time in the first half, seen any impact from sequestration.

As we go forward for the rest of the year, indeed, we believe that we will continue to see headwinds at the renewal level, but of course, the comparables will get a little bit easier as the year goes on because the non-renewals were already starting last year.

Looking out into 2015 and looking into the future, we believe and we see today that the sequestration process is not necessarily an underlying economics- or demand-driven process and yes, we believe that looking out into 2015 and beyond, that there's quite a strong underlying case for providing satellite capacity in Government Services and so we see that 2015, 2016 should be a recovering period, but we are cautious on 2014 and that's an area where we now begin to see some headwinds.

And that's one of the reasons why you may recall when we gave our three-year CAGR, that we said that the highest growth year would be in 2104 followed by 2016 and then we would see a much lower growth in 2016 and part of that is the timing of the ramp-up of SES-9.

A: So I would say, first of all, overall, and, I think, you may recall, I showed a slide on that in our Investor Day last June where if I recall correctly, over the last four to five years, in the kind of cost center - the costs related to variable costs.
I think we had a CAGR of something like about 0.2% which is way below inflation.
So as a company, we are very focused on managing cost.
And there's good costs and there's bad costs.

And we're very focused on pushing the good costs which are the things that we're doing in the international markets, and in the markets where we've increased our presence in the international markets, head count-wise, by over 300% since 2011.
We are pushing that very much, and that's what we call a good cost.
But there's also costs that we call bad costs.
And there, we are focusing on reducing those, and managing those, and that's very much part of the overall philosophy.

Now in the first quarter, the second element in the first quarter is that of that 7 million, a little bit less than a-third of it was due to lower transponder rental costs, if it is your second question.
But that just goes up and down.
You can't look at that on a quarter basis.
So the real thing is that we're focused on providing value and on good costs and bad costs, and we do everything we can to take out bad costs.
A: And in a sense, Sarah, if I may add to this, the faster we can move our capabilities in the regions, the more cost efficient we're going to be.
And if you had noted in my letter to the shareholders back in March, this is the point I've emphasized.
I think we scaled up the number of people deployed in the region by 50% over the course of 2014.
And the faster we do that, a, the better we can execute; and, b, the more we are cost efficient.
Q: So is that about basically a lower cost of labor, as in your resources are shifting to where there is less costly labor force?
Is that the point?

And obviously, at the same time, is a lower cost of operation in general.

A: And a much faster way of being able to execute.
If you have people deployed on the ground, they can gather insights that otherwise we won't have - we'd have to pay to sort of source and what have you.
So it's a very different set of capabilities which is why we've been very outspoken about this.
And I wouldn't be able to sort of pinpoint a single lever, because there is so much you could do with a single lever.
It's more sort of a philosophy how do you want to operate?
A: Correct.
And we've mentioned also I think in our last call, or one of our last meetings, the fact that we've been - something like 11 ERP systems into one.
So we've automated our systems, improved our systems.
These are giving us optimization in our cost base, right across our back offices.
So as Karim said, it's not any one element but it's really a focus on managing all this in an efficient basis while at the same time investing for growth.

Q: Thank you very much.
Just have three questions, please.
The first one on Ultra HD, it's very clear from your conference in February that you're monitoring developments in this area very closely.
And I probably ask this question every three months but just interested to hear any interesting updates that you're hearing either from broadcasters or other end users.

And the second question, O3b, since the launch in September 2014, I was just wondering if anything in particular surprised you in terms of what the network is delivering from again end-user feedback and any challenges that have risen.
And just lastly, just a point of confirmation, actually, on AMC-15, the further anomaly, could this further negatively impact revenues going forward?
Or has it effectively been taken into account with the recent renewal, i.e.
was the renewal expecting?
Or did it have a buffer within there for further anomalies?
Thank you.
A: I can just take the last one first, Paul.
So on the renewal, clearly, is there was some transponders not renewed.
There's a certain buffer now, but we're assuming that these will re-contract throughout the year.
So just like with any of the other satellites when we're providing our guidance, our guidance is always based on the health status.
And the fact that the one that we announced already at the beginning of the year, that's taken into account in all of this.
But of course, we can't rule out on any of the satellites any further health issues not having an impact.
But specifically for AMC-15, what we've announced is already considered in our guidance.
Q: Thank you.
A: Let me start with Ultra HD.
So what has significantly changed since our last conversation.
One is I had the opportunity of going very quickly through a report that SNR put out yesterday regarding their channel forecasts regarding DTH, in general.
And obviously, Ultra HD was part of their thought process.
Their numbers now are significantly higher than the initial forecast.
I think on the premise that they're seeing more and more content being produced plus all the other dynamics that we have covered in earlier discussions.

What is interesting and what I've observed in conversations with clients in recent months is that, now there's a clear understanding what generation 2, sort of, technical system should look like, so that there is an industry-wide alignment for launching the Ultra HD standard.
And so that would be the future proof.
But there are also considerations that the industry can launch Ultra HD or part of the industry can launch, in 2016, let's say, with the first generation.

So there was as you may recall, in one of the round tables or the forums we created or reinitiated earlier this year in London, healthy discussions about how do we make sure that we align all the standards and what is going to be a good enough platform to start with Ultra HD?
And there were diverging views.
There were views that were saying this can happen in 2016, this can happen in 2017.
I think where the chips are falling in is there is going to be in [indiscernible] with a sort of third generation in 2016 and the more sort of steady state which will be 2017, 2018.

And what is quite interesting is that over the course of this discussion, we have seen the emergence of Ultra HD on selected content on a commercial basis in the emerging markets which is quite a surprise because we always work with models that presume the start of Ultra HD primarily in the mature markets and there will be a phasing in the other markets.
So that I think is the meaningful change that - or I would say additional variable that came into the equation.
On O3b, the momentum is gathering faster and faster.

What surprised us, and I think it's an interesting way of asking the question, is the point that I've raised in my earlier briefing is and it has to do with the many conversations I've had with clients where their business is data-centric.

As part of the solution that they are seeking, there is always a question about how can we combine now the lower latency of O3b as part of the solution, particularly for certain applications that require, on the one hand, the wide beams' on the other hand, the high throughput and low latency?
And that was quite a surprise.
It was always a consideration of our thought process, and something that we wanted to, at some point, proactively push into the market.
We're seeing the market pulling for this much earlier than we anticipated.
But this is a good thing to deal with.
So I hope that I've, in some shape or form, have answered your questions.
Q: Yes, really helpful.
Thank you very much.
O: And we will take the next question from Giles Thorne.
Please go ahead.
Q: Hi there.
Thank you.
I have three questions, please.
Firstly, staying on the topic of O3b, the apparent diversification of O3b's commercial proposition into the US Government recently sounds very interesting.
And the recent progress looks promising, especially around getting the Schedule 70 accreditation.
What's missing is a bit more color on exactly which department within that very large customer base, and for what type of applications is O3b being considered?
And so, anything you could share on that front would be very helpful.
And staying on US Government, procurement innovation for the US Government has obviously been a snowballing theme over the past couple of years, especially around hosted payloads.
And now you've announced two in the past couple of weeks.
Would you be able to confirm that these are both under the HoPS agreement?
And also given these are two civilian applications as they were, when can we hope to see some military-hosted payloads start to come through?
And lastly, picking up on the SAT>IP Alliance that you announced at NAB earlier this year in Vegas.

Clearly, the idea of moving SAT>IP to being a built-in technology standard rather than a separate piece of hardware, is pretty exciting and dramatically improves satellite's effectiveness as a distribution medium in this changing world.
So that's all great.
What I wanted to get a sense of was your level of ambition.
Do you think this could truly be a global ubiquitous standard?
That was it.
Thanks.
A: Let me start with the third one.
So do we foresee this becoming ubiquitous?
Here is an interesting insight and again this is the benefit of spending a lot of time talking to clients.

When we are having conversation with the major operators who have been able to, on the one hand, be very successful in linear, so DTH, direct delivery to the home and on the other hand, launching a streaming on-the-go platform, what we're observing more and more is that, in fact, the on-the-go non-linear consumption is not necessarily happening on the go.
In fact, it's happening in the household.
And if you start looking at this and concerning the so-what of it, you realize how relevant that SAT>IP functionality can be.
And this has been our working premise from the beginning but there was always some sort of dichotomy separation between linear and non-linear.
Now having said that, if the majority of non-linear is happening in the home then I think creates a more acute need to make SAT>IP a widely available functionality.

Now had we moved from a very efficient technology to something that is ubiquitously available on the devices, or on the screens and what have you, the good news is that more and more the technology partners we work with, so the Panasonic and others, have now embedded SAT>IP in the big screens.
And there is a whole series of names that have embraced this technology.
So this is good news.
We still need to bring this into the set-up boxes at a faster pace.
So we've achieved very significant progress but that is not good enough.
And three is how do we start creating the incentive to use this functionality and measure the difference between a SAT>IP versus a not SAT>IP.
It's a long-winded answer but for you to appreciate that this is very important for us.
You put your fingers on the need.
How do we bring this into mainstream?

And so what we have elected to do this year is SES has funded -- so over and above the alliances, over and above bringing the technology and devices, we have funded the rollout of SAT>IP in not an insignificant number of - the inclusion in non-insignificant number of devices to be placed in a non-insignificant number of homes in a very important European market.
And at the moment, there is a market test that is running to quantify the impact of the SAT>IP experience versus a non-SAT-IP-enabled household which, in our model, is going to be quite significant.
And that will immediately start creating the awareness why this is making difference.
And again, if you go back to the insight I shared with you at the outset, that most of the non-linear consumption is actually happening in the home.
SAT>IP therefore has a wide and a ready field to enable - not occupy - but enable.
So that takes care, I think, of the SAT>IP thing.

On the O3b, what I can state is what I think has been echoed already in some of the press releases, is that the demos that were conducted in the US were conducted with Sencom and other operational security-centric agencies in the US So ultimately, you have to envisage that these are the applications that these are the end clients that we envision to be using the O3b capabilities.

Now this does not exclude and, in fact, some of the earlier commercial agreements that we have seen on O3b, and these will be announced fairly soon, but again, you have to appreciate that, SES GS, our subsidiary, will make these announcements separately, are going to be also with civilian agencies.
On the second question I think it was regarding the nature of the hosted payloads.
I'm not sure what was the exact question.

Q: It was these contracts that have been won under the HoPS scheme and when can we expect to see some hosted payloads in the military applications, or military agencies, rather than in, in inverted commas, civilian agencies?
Thanks.
A: Yes.
The two applications are - let me step back.
The hosted payloads on SES-14 and SES-15 are serving different applications.
One of them is to augment, I think, an imagery system.
The other one is related to...
A: GPS.
A: ...the GPS.
A: Yes, they're not military payloads.
One is an augmentation system for aircraft, like we had already announced with EGNOS but the US equivalent.
So the ultimate user is the US FAA, the ultimate user, and then that's on SES-15.
In respect to the hosted payload on SES-14, that's to the University of Colorado, so scientific applications, ultimately.
A: The hosted payload on the military side has to fall within a sort of dedicated policy, and there is a lot of work that's being done in that vein.
As you may appreciate there has been, I think, rich views about the pros and cons of this approach.
And I think increasingly they're seeing more favorable views on sort of teaming up with commercial operators.
And given, I think, the credibility and the track record of SES GS, I do not exclude that the ones in the foreseeable future are going to be also inclusive of military payloads.
Q: Thank you very much.
And care to throw just five seconds at rumors that the CHIRP payload could be switched back on or is that a no comment?
A: I'd say that one is a no comment, Giles.
Q: Very good.
Thank you very much.
O: And we're now moving to Laurie Davison with Deutsche Bank.
Please go ahead.
Q: Hello guys.
It's Laurie here from Deutsche.
The first question is just to follow up on SAT>IP which is have you actually had any formal contract signed for SAT>IP services?
The second is on a warning of STMicro today that Ultra HD 4K chips were being delayed by around 12 months.

Just wondered whether you've got any insights into that and whether that was factored into the comments you were saying earlier on about the core part of the demand coming in 2017, 2018, rather than 2016?
The third question was just over the trimming of the bundle in the - amongst US operators.
We've heard DIRECT and DISH talk about potential trimming in the terms of channel numbers in response to some of the subscriber declines they've seen.
Have you seen any evidence of that in your negotiations with US operators?
Thank you.
A: Let me start with the third question, the answer is, no, we haven't seen that.
On Ultra HDs, to clarify, what I said is not that this -- the event of it is 2017.
No, the question that was raised is what has evolved since the last conversation?

So over and above the traction on the screens, the content being produced, what have you, what is clear is that a conversation that was initiated at the start of the year, and part of it, in fact, surfaced during the forum that we organized in London by bringing the main stakeholder, is, a, what are the standards that we need to align; and what is going to be the first and the second line of alignment?
So my comment was adding more specifics on these questions by saying the first line of alignment would happen in 2016, and the second line would happen in 2017.
And it may well be that the sort of reference to the chip that you'd raised is part of 2017 but this does not going to preclude the initial launch in 2016.
On SAT>IP, to be very clear, SES has developed this technology, and has offered it to the industry.
And what this technology does is it enriches the end-user experience in the household.
We do not sell more or less capacity on the premise of SAT>IP.
But we have said time and again, and certainly I have been quite vocal about it, we have a responsibility to continuously think about how do we enrich the end user experience.
And SAT>IP is going to be very critical to that.

And as we have now aligned the Panasonic, the LG, the Samsung of this world to embed it in their screens, and as we have aligned, in a very large number of set-top manufacturers, and embedding that chip in their screens, we also want to make sure that we create traction in the end-user home.
And again, we're saying this without being the pay TV operator.
We don't operate these platforms.
But we believe we have a role to play to sort of say, look, this is the kind of paradigm shift that it creates.
And so my comment was for you, collectively, to appreciate that we take SAT>IP very seriously and want to see it all the way through the end-user experience.

The one exception, I would say, is that where we have a direct sort of experience with it which is sort of auguring very well, is in the case of HD+, because it's a platform that we manage end to end with our broadcaster partners.
This is where we see it through.
And again, we have the privilege of controlling the entire ecosystem and being able to measure the end user experience.
So I want to clarify that we're not in the business of making money out of SAT>IP.
We're in the business of thinking about what is the future-proof application of our infrastructure.
And that's one way of doing it, by making sure that our infrastructure is not limited to big screen but it travels in the house.
I hope I've answered your question, Laurie.
Q: Yeah, it was more of whether any other operators either on the video side or actually on the integrated sets side, that actually started to deploy services that we might have missed.
I'd seen HD+ deployment of the service but I was just wondering whether there are any others who are actively using it already?
A: Again, we're sort of bound by confidentiality agreement.
A number of the operators we work with have this as part of their requirements for the next generation of set-top boxes.

And alternatively, what was very interesting in recent conversations I've had with clients and again joining my commercial beliefs is , that there is an alternative technology, very comparable to SAT>IP, that provides the same feature.
And for us, it serves the same purpose, at the end of the day.
Again, we created that standard and offered it.
So whether it's going to be SAT>IP or something comparable that takes the linear feed and distribute it IP-wide into the home, is going to be there.
And there may well be, and there is, I can confirm that, other DTH operators who are prosecuting a comparable technology and embedding it as part of their specs.
And that is perfectly fine for us because again it provides the end objective that we are focusing on.
Q: Okay.
That's very clear.
Thank you.
A: Thank you.
O: Thank you.
And we are now moving to David Strauch with CA CIB.
Please go ahead.
Q: Yes, thank you.
Just a follow-up on O3b and your comments on the positive momentum you see.
Could this strong demand accelerate the timeline for taking full control of 03b, or does it not really change anything for the time being?
A: Okay.
Is it going to change the timeline?

The horizon for us to consider the consolidation of O3b, so taking control, i.e., moving from our 45% to 50.1%, or any number above 50.1%, is a horizon that we have defined in our mind anywhere between the end of this year, so end of 2015 through 2016.
And so that is the horizon that we are working with.
There are a few conditions precedent that will have to prevail for us to move the needle on this.
But as you rightly noted, some of these indicators are moving faster than, in a pleasant way, faster than initially envisaged.
But that window is clear in our mind.
And I'm glad to re-confirm it on this call.
Q: Okay, thank you.

Mark Roberts: Thank you very much, Simona.
Thank you, Karim.
Thank you, Padraig and to John.

We continue to be available for you, if you have any further questions.
In the meanwhile, I wish you a very good weekend.
Bye-bye.

Thank you all for your participation, ladies and gentlemen, and you may now disconnect.
Q&A
O: Thank you.
If you would like to ask a question at this time please press the star or asterisk key followed by the digit one on your telephone.
Please insure that the mute button on your telephone is switched off to allow your signal to reach our equipment.
We will pause for a moment to allow everyone to signal.
We will now take our first question from Giles Thorne from Jefferies.
Q: Hi, there.
Morning, guys.
It's Giles here from Jefferies.
I have three questions, please, a couple on O3b and then another on operations.
So it's quite a high-level first question.
As you begin to exercise or think about exercising your operational control, what changes can we expect to see at O3b?
And in particular, I am remembering Steve Collar's teasing of a major upscaling in the O3b constellation.
Is this still on the cards under SES's stewardship?
And second question, O3b.
There's been some evident stays or concerns around an equity placing of late following a larger than normal request to issue shares at the AGM.
I appreciate, today, you are not actually signaling that you are going to move to 100%.
But in a scenario that you do, how are you viewing funding for the next 50% purchase of $710 million?
And lastly, picking up on some of the teasing from Martin Halliwell at the June event last year around space talks.
You've now been associated with Orbital ATK's MEV-1 vehicle.
What - you'd probably be MEV-2 or MEV-3, but regardless, could you give us a sense of your objectives for this program?
The CapEx implications look to be meaningful.
Can we expect Martin to extend the CapEx reduction program beyond 2018 at the CMD in June this year?
That was it.
Thank you.
A: Good.
So, Giles, why don't I take questions one and three, and I would hand over to Padraig for the second one.
So the changes - it's not changes that are expected; it's more in our view, an evolution.
I think the first evolution in terms of acceleration is, how do we jointly accelerate the commercial or the go-to-market synergies.

For all the right reasons we'd be teaming with O3b, but we're being careful all the way to make sure that we are doing this considering that we're only one of many shareholders without management control.
That now can be much further accelerated, which means that we can approach clients with a holistic, integrated solution.
We can do this with much better coordination.
I think we can share a lot of the insights and the foresight, now that we have that.
In a previous setting, was a bit more challenging to do.
And so, for me, number one priority is go-to market, how we accelerate this.
Number two, to your point is, now that the O3b technology and the SES technology are under one group, what are the opportunities to further synergize?

And as we think to our HTS program, because SES already has a very significant budget appropriation in terms of building future assets with hybrid capability, hybrid taking into account a lot of HTS differentiation that's going to bring in, now, we have the ability to do this jointly thinking with O3b.

And in some cases, we may come to a conclusion that deploying a GEO capability may be more appropriate for the type of application we want to serve versus other cases where a MEO capability will be much more relevant.
And these conversation now can happen in perfect sort of coordination, both at the level of our technology team and also with our industrial partner.
For all the right reason previously, we were not able to bring these three pieces together in one group all the time.
And now, I think we can further accelerate this.
And last but not least, from an operational standpoint, there's a lot of things that we could do now under the single roof.

Financial synergy, as noted by Padraig is one of them, but I can think about, how do we go about our human capital development; how do we go about deploying our capability across all important markets we want to serve.
And so, that for me is going to be an acceleration that we always have in mind.
We were sort of executing on some of the elements, but certainly not at a holistic level.
And now, it's a completely different ballgame for this tie-up between SES and O3b.
On the third question, when it comes to sort of space talks, for us the approach - and so, as you rightly noted, Martin has been very engaged with a number of industrial partner.
You've mentioned one.
We are in discussion with others.
The concept of a space talk is twofold for us.

One is, effectively how do we extend the life of some of the important satellite programs we have where the decision to renew these programs or amend these program can be further delayed so that from a capital allocation standpoint we can re-prioritize other initiatives we want to prosecute .
So, that is one of them.

But equally important, the concept of a space talk - and I remember vividly Martin saying this; it's not just about extending the life of a satellite; is about the ability to create a persistent platform in space, i.e., in the future I would not exclude that the satellite platform is persistent in space, and through the space talk mechanism or network, we'll be able to take out some elements of an aging satellite and replace it with a new element because in many - or in some of these cases, that is really what is relevant to us.

And through this, we will not just be extending the life of a satellite with a technology that was designed 15 years ago; we'll be able to plug into the satellite an upgraded technology, which again fits perfectly well with our approach to building hybrid satellites.
On this note, I will hand over to Padraig.
A: Yeah.
Thank you.
Giles, on your second question, so first of all, indeed as you said, the investment decision always comes first before the financing decision.
And on the investment decision, this would always be treated like any other investment decision.
It needs to be subject to satisfying SES's investment hurdle rates.
As we've explained, O3b Board had decided to evaluate an IPO.
There's a call and put option, and all this I think is well in line with the agreement.

Now, should such an exercise of the call option become relevant, again, assuming it all meets the hurdle rates, and then also depending on the timing, all potential financing sources including capital markets will be evaluated to determine the most appropriate financing option.
And all this would be done in keeping with SES's commitment to our investment grade rating, which is a fundamental part of our financial framework.
Q: Very clear.
Thanks, guys.
