Please go ahead.
Q: Yes.
Hello.
Two questions if I may.
The first one is on your operational.
You mentioned you actually lost 22 utilized transponder in the quarter.
I was wondering what region or what exactly are these 22 transponders utilized decline this quarter?
And my second question is on O3b.
You've given an O3b CapEx guidance, but you haven't updated your long-term SES guidance.

Does that mean that implicitly, on your uncommitted CapEx that you always put in your CapEx guidance does these include O3b for - will we see an increase in your CapEx guidance once you include O3b during your Capital Day presentation?
Thank you.
A: Yeah.
Thanks, Eric .
So, on the second question, actually we do - we include our long-term CapEx guidance.
It's on page 22 of the first quarter results, hedged, and this CapEx guidance is [indiscernible] always SES-only and does not include O3b.
And you see the O3b committed CapEx in their slide.
With respect to the second question on the utilization of capacity, what we see across the quarter is utilization reduced by 29 transponders.
It represents about 1% of the available inventory.
Yet there was no reduction from Video in the period.
It's simply the normal ebb and flow of data-centric traffic, mainly Enterprise and Government.
We saw a similar trend, by the way in the same time last year, which went from 72.7% to 71.4% and then climbed back in the second quarter.
Q: Thank you.
O: We will now take our next question from Simon Cooke, Insight Investment.
Please go ahead.
Q: Hi.
Thanks for taking the question.
Just a quick one on the financing.
I know you flagged that you could refinance 25% of the O3b's debt relatively quickly.
Could you just talk us through what you are weighing up in terms of refinancing the whole of the 1.2 billion post-closing just so we can get an idea from - for those of us on the debt side?
Thanks.
A: Sure.
So obviously, with SES as the 50.5% shareholder, we would limit any activity on the financing to reflect our 50.5% shareholding.
And of course that will be a different position, should we own 100%.

And then at 50.5% shareholding and also related to the portfolio of the O3b debt and looking at what's possible, there is a possibility to refinance one of the facilities which represents about 25% of the overall debt and where the average interest rate is a little bit - where the interest rate of that facility is a little bit higher than the average interest rate of O3b.
But again, that 50.5%, we would only be walking like a shareholder at 50.5% and that's why you are talking only about 25%.
Q: Okay.
Thank you.
O: We will now take our next question from Ben Heelan from BoQ .
Please go ahead.
Q: Hi.
Thank you.
It's Ben from Bank of America.
Just a quick question on the impact of O3b on potentially cannibalizing the existing revenues in the Enterprise business.
And with the high throughput network, SES-12, SES-14 and SES-15 and the O3b network, I mean, any risk on - or any comments on the impacts on pricing etcetera?
Thank you.
A: The short answer would be, no.

O3b has been in the market since September 2014 and the commercial traction that has been achieved has been achieved with all the other commercial parameter including pricing; and the same way when it comes to SES.

In fact, in the cases where we brought the two capabilities together for some of our client, the consideration for taking onboard this combined capability was mostly around the value-add that you bring.
And in our view, it has deemphasized any price pressure that we could have been subjected to.

And that is the idea; the more we can depreciate on the product and the solution, the less likely you're going to be subjected to sort of the pricing pressure that would [indiscernible] service offering.
And that has been consistent with our approach to the data-centric market verticals since 2014.
Q: Thank you.
O: We will now take our next question from Robert Berg from Berenberg.
Please go ahead.
Q: Hi there.
Yeah.
Thanks.
Couple of my questions already answered.
But a follow up on the last one.
I remember you used to say, there's about $50 million of SES existing group revenue that was potentially cannibalized by O3b.
Obviously the upside seems to be much larger if O3b is going to do 100 million revenues this year.

Could you give us maybe an update on the 50 million of - I think it's mainly point-to-point applications like trunking and mobile backhaul, especially given the impact on the Enterprise business last year.

And the second question, just interested to know what the board would be taking into consideration of O3b when deciding on whether to have an IPO or not and on how the board structure is; are you over 50% of the board?
Thanks.
A: Yeah.
So let me try to address these.

I think the sort of - the thesis that was presented many, many years ago around the 50 million was presented I think at the time where we had our assumptions on how some of the data-centric markets would evolve.
That 50 million cannibalization hasn't materialized in the case of SES.
I mean, just to give you a sort of a picture of this.
This was made at the time when for example we were not present in the aeronautical market, which is a very significant data-centric.
So I think markets have evolved in such a manner and we've evolved our positioning in these markets so that that cannibalization exposure, in our view, has become [indiscernible] .
And so what O3b does is it brings the number of incremental and accretive elements to the data-centric propositions that we have.
Now, what this would do, it would certainly compete with the other HTS programs in the broader market.
But when we were designing SES-12, SES-14 and SES-15, we were designing this with a view that at some point in time we would take control of O3b, and I personally have been very explicit about that.
And certainly, [indiscernible] before me has done this.

So we've made sure that as we go through our fleet development and our go-to-market approach, we didn't want to run into that hypothesis of a 50 million, although we put it out there to make sure that we appreciated the risk at the outset.
So I think we're in a much better place today.
On the second question, when it comes to sort of the evolution of the corporate governance of O3b post taking control, so once we have closing, we indeed have a majority of the board.

And so, without getting into the detail exactly the - we will be able along with the other shareholders to have a more influential say in the oversight of the company, whether it's from a strategy standpoint, whether it's from a investment standpoint, particularly on capital allocation, and last but not least in terms of how do we oversee the performance of the company in perfect sort of synergy and sort of accretive integration with SES, things that for all the right reasons we could not bring together to the extent that we could realize the full potential in a setup where we are only playing our, sort of role on the board among the other shareholders.

And that is very well understood with other shareholders, and certainly from our side, from the side of the other shareholders and, certainly, from the side of the management team on both the O3b and the SES side.
That's a sort of a great outlook for us to pursue.
Q: Okay.
Great.
Thank you.
O: We will now take our next question from Chris Ager from Goldman Sachs.
Please go ahead.
Q: Hello.
Good morning, everyone.
This is actually Igor Ostrowski from Goldman Sachs Asset Management.
I had a quick follow-up question on the three options.
Based on the existing business plans for SES and for O3b, which of these options do you think is most likely?
Which is the preferred option?
What in your mind is the best-case scenario or the worst-case scenario there?
A: So, at this stage, we need to have the optionalities.

And what we wanted to do at the outset is to make sure that these optionalities are clear, not just in terms of conceptually what they are, but also what are the associated economics with each one of them.
And I think that was the major, sort of evolution that we've made to our thought process.

Because the two-step approach has been part of our narrative for the past 6.5 years; starting with an IPO, having a put towards the end and having the ability to negotiate also an acquisition between these two milestone was always part of the dynamics that we have between the SES as a shareholder and the non-SES shareholders of O3b.
At this stage, our priority to make sure that we have these optionalities.
What was very clear on our mind was that at some point in time, we will take control.
We always said, first, taking control, whether we fully acquire or the rest - the balance would go public through an IPO.

Really means that myself - that at least we want to give sort of - we want to anchor these optionality in a manner where the day we decide to execute one of these optionalities, we are able to do so with full transparency and, equally important, in full compliance with our financial framework.
So we have to balance the consideration of fully acquiring O3b in our view with all the other strategic priorities that we at SES are pursuing.
And we have now the ability to think through this question while being in control of O3b, so we have a tie-up.

A: Giles, I'll take the second question regarding Virtual Reality.

MX1 has been doing quite significant work in that vein.
And I would certainly invite [indiscernible] in June to sort of expand on this including addressing your question regarding the transponder requirement.

Because the thing that I would like to underscore, this is not just about providing sort of the distribution channel as such, but also providing the network architecture on the site and between one site and the other to be able to create that experience which MX1 was able to do during the Super Bowl game recently.
Taking over also the third question.
So, you're absolutely right.
Inclined capacity is proving to be very valuable.
I would just sort of put the relevance of this on one criteria, and we've always viewed our differentiation in Mobility as part of our value stack.
So what a inclined orbit brings to the table are number of things.
One is the assets that we're putting in place have a wide coverage area.
It starts with that, and obviously, the performance of the satellite.
But the coverage area is absolutely instrumental.
It has to be on the relevant route.
And because of our scale and because of the diversity of our assets, we're pretty much in a unique position to be able to answer that.
The second one is it's being used particularly in situations where rapid augmentations or i.e., scaling up bandwidth is required, and so we can bring in these assets very quickly.
Either these assets are located where the traffic is supposed to be or we can relocate these assets and we have to have the orbital slot as well as the spectrum.
The third one I would say also are the favorable economics.
The fourth one is very importantly it's backward compatible.

So, when we have an IFC operator that has to scale up the bandwidth and the coverage or the delivery per airplane within a certain SLA, they can do that immediately with our inclined orbit asset, and all of this is backward compatible.

And the last one I would say is a very important parameter is it's providing further resilience to the network that they are building i.e., we don't end up with networks that have a single-point of failure.
So, they have a highly sort of valued asset that performs very well.
But if there's a technical mishap on this asset that creates on its own a single point of failure.
And so the resilience is very important to our aeronautical client.

Yesterday, I was in a meeting with one of those - one of the seniors in the airlines industry and resilience is one of the instrumental elements as part of the whole process and the regions that we were discussing was the region where we are able to deploy multiple assets specifically to address the resilience question.

Looking now on the margin, the key development in the first quarter is the increase in the variable cost of sales, and the variable cost of sales is driven by the fact that there is a very strong ramp-up in the O3b business and there is a variable cost of sales associated with this, once you sign up the customer, once you install the networks which puts the networks in place.

Q: Hi, everybody.

And of that, if you could talk a little bit more about which of those there's a sort of risk of cannibalization from high-throughput O3b, rather than the complementarity that you have talked about today.

And given the concerns that you have mentioned around the structural outlook for data services, I wondered if there'd be scope in the future to provide more granular reporting on a per-application basis.

And secondly, just following up on O3b, I just wondered if you remain comfortable with the O3b business plan, which sets out expected revenue of $40 million per satellite after the initial ramp-up period.

The growth in the paying customers accelerated materially this quarter.

A: Okay.
So, Mark, I'll try to respond to your questions.
On the first one, to give you a very precise number, at the time when we invested in O3b, we looked obviously at our revenue composition.
And at that time - and the number probably has not changed dramatically.
At that time, we had identified that the applications that would be addressed more efficiently by O3b is leading in SES' account to 50 million of revenues per year.
So, if you want - if over time, these applications would move from geostationary bent-pipe satellites to O3b, it's an amount of 50 million that would transit from SES to O3b.
Having said this really, the applications that are of, let's say, most interest for SES, as you know, will be broadcast with 70%, if I look at these wins on page eight.
Enterprise VSAT is also - is the main bulk of - with oil and gas and mining - also the main bulk of what we have in our data business.
Trunking is very low, probably 3% to 4%.

And as I said before, we have in many of these applications, customers who need the capacity for point to multi-point communication, and this will not be taken over by high-throughput satellites, be it geostationary, be it O3b.
So, we only foresee for SES a very low number and a low percentage of our revenues, if you want, shifting over time to O3b.

And you should not forget that that's not any way to look at it because we have already announced a couple of contracts where O3b and SES succeeded to sign contracts with customers where the customer did take in the package deal SES geostationary satellite capacity and O3b capacity.
And some of these deals are - that they want to take geostationary satellite because O3b - before O3b is available.
And in other deals, it's really a mixture of SES geostationary capacity and of O3b capacity also to continue in the future.
So, don't look at this simply as a risk for SES to lose revenues.

In that, for clear - for sure as this is, even if you forget about O3b-specific revenues, the net result of this is that there will be incremental revenue for SES because of the coupling of these different satellite solutions to the customer - to one or the same customer.
Yes, I think the revenue per satellite of O3b has been indicated to go up to $40 million per satellite after the ramp-up period.

Simply when you model this, please take into account that in all satellites, be it O3b, be it geostationary satellites, the ramp-up period is really some years, and so don't be too aggressive when you really calculate over this ramp-up period.

And then HD+, and I think I explained also why it's, for example, when you have the beam on O3b that it's taken partly by a customer, then you fix the coverage of that beam, and then O3b sales team have to find customers in that very same beam that cannot be moved.
And so, that's why there is a ramp-up per beam and not only a ramp-up per satellite.
And then HD+ subscriber numbers, it's really very maybe conservative our, let's say, target for the year.

But there was also an acceleration, obviously, in the first half regarding - last year regarding paying HD+ subscribers because of some sport events that happened middle of the year with, I think, the European Soccer Championship and with the Olympic Games in London.
So that's why the increase of the HD+ users in the second half of 2012 has been slower than it has been in the first half.
And that's also what we try to take into account when we guide to the number at the end of the year.

So I'm just wondering whether you expect a very quick ramp-up on those satellites.

Q: Yes.
You talked about the delayed ASTRA 5B.
I wonder if you get any compensation related to that.
A: No.
You know, that there are some compensations if there are problems with satellites in orbit.
Regarding late delivery, there are also some compensations if delayed delivery from satellite manufacturer.
But in these cases, the satellites are all available.
So, it's about the launch vehicle and the contracts defining a window for the launch.
And so, contractually, the launch vehicle service provider is bound to a window.
And if the only, let's say, action that we can take is that if the launch falls outside of that window, then we can terminate the contract at no cost.
Obviously, that's the only remedy that we have available for us.

But in these cases where the launch delays are two months, three months, obviously, there is not a possibility to build up an alternative in such a short timeframe because you would need to adopt another launch for the specific satellite.
We have the multi-launch agreement in place.
So that would allow us to swap launchers.
But if we swap launcher, it takes roughly six months before you can launch the same satellite on another launcher.

So these delays, which are mainly, as you can see from this table, three months on average probably, these delays are not long enough in order to justify termination of the contract by us and bringing the satellites to another launcher.
A: And perhaps, Nick, on the other two questions, so on the 6 million related to AMC-9, so there's no cost associated with that, and therefore, that's also at the EBITDA level.

And then with regard to the 18 million in the launches, so I think perhaps the best way to look at it from an overall reasonableness point of view is if you look at the total number of months in delay here, back, of course, to the 22nd of February, I think it comes out at something like about 10 months.
And then looking at the 18 million, I mean, that's less than 2 million a month per satellite, which is a very reasonable amount.
Obviously, we don't break out the detail per satellite because of confidentiality.
But as we've said in the first quarter results, including SES-6, we had over 50% of the capacity contractors.
And now, for the remaining three satellites to be launched, the pre-fill rate would be a little bit under 50%, because obviously, SES-6 also had Oi in there.
So I think that's the way to look at it.
And yeah, that's what it is.

So I wouldn't make to - for us, it's really inherent in the overall growth.

In Africa, in Eastern Europe, so this continues to be the case.

And the customer is also recognizing the value creation that we bring to their business.
So that's the first thing.
And the second thing is that quite often, the customer is really not only leasing capacity with a fixed number of transponders but has also an option to increase the capacity over time.
And then, obviously, the price is also fixed already in this contract because the options are part of the contract.
Clearly, that's not the case.

And if a customer doesn't want to contract for more capacity and then he or she comes back after five years and says I want to have more capacity, then clearly that there is a leverage in the negotiation for the satellite operator.
A: Yeah.
And, Eric, on the question on the margin, I mean, to - you really have to look at the underlying numbers.

In other words, you have to back out the analog impact because the analog impact is, as I said already, it technically has a bigger impact on the EBITDA than it has in the revenue because the denominator - the absolute amount of EBITDA is small.
And if you look now at the six months, you will see the revenue growth at 7.2%; you see the EBITDA growth at the 6.4%.

And as I just outlined, in the second half of the year with the SES-6 capacity coming on-line, with the other new deals coming on-line, with the African deals coming on-line, this will accelerate the infrastructure growth.
So, I think, to have a meaningful view of EBITDA, you have to look at it excluding the analog numbers.

Q: And thank you.
Just three quick questions, please.
Firstly, in terms of Ultra HD, I was just wondering if you could maybe expand on some of the points you made in the presentation.
Are there any interesting recent data points or experience that you had, feedback from broadcasters or consumers over the past three months especially during the World Cup period?
And secondly and 2013 is obviously a very tough year for the industry with African oversupply and US DoD.
I was just wondering going forward from here, what sort of percent of your revenues will come from these areas, especially given that the recent Pathfinder and CWG contracts?
And just lastly on SES-12, I'm just interested to see, we'll have significant amount of spot beams on the satellite.
I was just wondering what sort of markets are you targeting in terms of the multi-beam footprint.
Thank you.
A: Okay.
Let's start with the first one, and thank you for the questions.
On Ultra High Definition, look, my highest level of observation would be to say we're seeing a number of significant elements in the ecosystem to take shape.
First, the standard.
There is now a much more unit-wide view of what the standard is, how do we define it, how everyone works with it.
And in fact, as a case in point, recently, the EBU came out and said, look, from our perspective, this is how it's going to look like and how we expect others to work with.
And we're part of these conversations.
Two, is on the content with the number of clients who are not just broadcasters but who are also invested in producing original content.
And we're talking about Tier 1 clients across the globe, whether it's in North America, Europe or Asia.
Their current modus operandi has it that the majority of the content is being filmed in 4K.
This is not to say that the processing is being done in 4K.
We're not at that point yet.

But the original footage is in 4K, which effectively means that once Ultra High Definition becomes a sort of a mass application, which we see happening over the next two to three years, sort of the difficulty in transition from SD to HD and sort of all the augmentation or transfer that's effort to have to, we will not have to face them.

The important thing is for us to accelerate all of this as an industry, so the entire video ecosystem, is that from the point that this is filmed into 4K to the point where it can be broadcasted and received in the household in 4K, the elements in the middle are all 4K compatible and sort of we're increasing the same traction in this.
And last but not least is when it comes to the actual TV panels and sort of get them at a size and at a price point that is attractive.

What is interesting is at the start of the year, there were some projections as to the number of - the growth in the number of new screens sold, which now we're seeing, and these were statements that were made by a number of manufacturer, went up by 30%, 40% and 45%.
And the working-in hypothesis of the number of this or a very significant amount of this growth was for high-definition screens.
And as they come under the $1,000 or 1,000 price point, it becomes very attractive.
So all of these have to start up together.
There isn't going to be a single silver bullet but, certainly, we're seeing this happening.
And last but not least is, as I've mentioned, the sheer fact that our clients are running trials with us on this gives us confidence that this is around the corner.
To move to the second point, our view is that the government business is sort of going through two different dynamics.
But before I get to the dynamics, the fundamental question is about demand.
Would the US government continue to have sustained, if not, growing demand for satellite-based applications and, therefore, satellite-based access?
The answer is yes.

In fact, as you may have seen in recent announcement, the US administration is thinking increasingly how the industry can scale up and become more and more sort of self-sustaining because that's a very important part of how they conduct their business and their activities.
So that is the overall demand.

There is one dynamic that is subject to the budget sequestration, which we have experienced but to a lesser extent vis--vis other service providers in the industry because of the nature of our contracts with them.

And two, the sort of the counter dynamic is, as this was happening, the government was open to conversation about how they can procure satellite capacity and/or access in a way that is compliant with the new directives, and this is where programs like Pathfinders, where we sort of introduced the ideas, came to bear.
And there are other programs that are underway that are under decision.
I'm in no position to disclose them, but these are the sort of work that we are doing.

So in a sense, it gives us significant confidence that as far as SES is concerned, that's the business that we'll continue to support and a business that will continue to generate consistent revenue for us.
For SES-12, the question is what is the relevance of adding the HTS capacity and, importantly, to adding the digital processors.

We've been in a number of situations, I briefly mentioned earlier, where there was marked demand for capacity, either from institutional clients, governments and others or for clients in the mobility verticals that could not be optimally served on our traditional wide-beam satellite.
So you could do that, but either the quality of the experience is not there and/or the price point would not be there.

And so with these two now, with the features that we've introduced, which is HTS and the dynamic processing, it allows now to serve this pent-up demand that, again, we have been experiencing for quite some time and this is why we wanted to make sure that as we go through the replacement of SES-12, which is built on very important orbital slot for us, we also have that flexibility.
I hope I've answered your questions.
Q: Yeah, it's very interesting.
Thank you very much.

A: Okay.

In any sense we have to be proactive to always sort of think through how can we better serve them?

It is not a single-year award.

On Mexico, the short answer would be we're looking at this opportunity like other opportunities that would fit within our priorities, either they are geographically-related priorities or market vertical priorities.
And in this sense, Mexico would fit both of these in terms of serving a very significant part of Latin America and be serving the data market and the video market.

It was important for us to have the optimal replacement for our DTH capacity and also sort of be able to add to that since we have been significantly constrained in this part of the world on that particular satellite.

And, obviously, being able to move to electrical propulsion allowed us to sort of utilize the mass for something else, something else being adding the additional eight Ku transponders since we have the frequencies but simply we did not have the capacity utilized now.

I think the other variances we needed to address, we wanted to address, the data requirements for our clients and some of these clients are Asia-based, some of these clients are institutional or outside Asia, who are seeking to serve their requirements there.
And we could only do that via the innovation we're introducing, which is HTS with the digital processors.
And there's only a handful of manufacturers who are, in our view, at the forefront of this kind of sort of technology combination.
And in our sort of processing and selecting the manufacturer, we have considered most of the vendors who could use that size, so that mass of platform because that's a very important point.
These platforms and the mass that they have to carry, in a sense, each of the manufacturer has the differentiated capabilities in the different sizes and tonnage.
And at the outset, we've got fortunately factories who could address all requirements and then through a rigorous process that took some time because this is a quite innovative mission.
Airbus presented us with a more significant one, but we did approach a number of other manufacturers and Boeing was certainly one of them.
The next one, Padraig?

And so that continues to be work in progress, but it has no bearing on it.

Now within that base of 15% -

At the same time, the depreciation has also moved and whenever there is a satellite delay as a lot of the CapEx is also staggered, the CapEx is equally moved and so it's a timing issue.
A: Yeah.

Up on the earlier question regarding the market share, while there is no public information from the pace of new business we're generating, we're either spending market share or in fact well increasing it.
From what we could pick up in terms of the demand that we're seeing in the overall part of that segment and versus what we're realizing, we're probably picking up market share.
But then again, we have to see until the end of that phase.
Now, what is the perspective in the medium to long-term?

On the one hand, there is an increasing demand for satellite enabled solutions from the US government, whether it's because of applications over North America or applications Internationally, Pathfinder is a case in point.
Two is because of increasing requirements for high bandwidth applications.
As an example, UABs for the purpose of surveillance and UABs may well represent close to 50% of the potential - the total capacity that will be required by US government.
So when you look at these prospects, they all bode well for satellite enabled application.
The question is, when these will become sort of - at a scale that will compensate for sequester, and that in our view is a 2015, 2016 cycle.

We believe that we now have a better understanding of the cycle versus mid last year where I would say at the start of this year, but I would not exclude that we will continue to experience some of the sequels of the budget sequestration during the quarter of 2015.

The onus on us, as we have done this year, is continue to prosecute new business whether that new business is adequately formulated by our clients, or we actually work with our client to frame these programs.

Pathfinder was a program where we and one of our competitors in this case, Intelsat, we worked on framing what these requirements are and have been in the US government come up with a procurement process that would be mutually beneficial.
And by the end of the day, Pathfinder became a reality.
There are other programs in the pipeline that we can talk about once they become part of the public domain.
Q: That's very interesting.
So, just a quick follow-up.

So to understand, you think there's sort of cycle and change in the dynamic about how the US government procures capacity will kind of have played out by 2015, 2016 and then we're kind of into the new - that new dynamic.
A: Yeah.
2015, 2016 is the runway where I think the industry will be probably fully experiencing the impact of the budget sequester.
I think the dynamic in terms of safety through - what is the best way for the US government to procure capacity from commercial operator is going to be an ongoing process.

What may have happened is because of the budget sequester, the incentive for collaboration has, in fact, increased and we were able to sort of introduced the ideas at a much faster pace than in previous years.
So, I hope in one way or another, I've answered your question.
Q: That's great.
Thank you very much.
A: Thanks.

A: And maybe, Sarah, just to fully clarify your two question.
The 96 transponders I mentioned to you is capacity within Europe.

And as I said, on top of that, there will be some incremental outside of Europe 2G capacity.
A: Padraig, do you want to take the third question regarding the excess cash flow?
A: Yes.
On the access cash flow, the overall headroom in general, there has been no change to what we've said during our Investor Day on this topic.
So we continue to see a process of deleveraging.
As I said earlier the number that we see now at the end of September is temporarily inflated due to FX and this just automatically corrects itself.
But if we look over the life of the - over the next number of years, normally we're giving that guidance out to the period 2018, 2019.
If you take the CapEx profile that we've have outlined today on page 17, which includes not only the progress under construction but also it includes four more programs as of yet to be committed.

If you take on top of that the fact that we are committed to a progressive dividend and also then look at the fact that we want to manage the business under the threshold of 3.3 times and when we look at all that together, it generates an approximate indicative overall headroom of around 2.8 billion to 3 billion.
And again, as we're looking over a longer period, this is order of magnitude and is very approximate.
And so all that is - our operating free cash flow is ahead this year compared to last year, all that is continuing.

And then finally - but again that's not now a short-term objective of management, but what we have clearly shown in the past is that what it also makes sense to the capital allocation perspective, we have also increased cash returns to shareholder through the buyback of shares.
So all of this, I would say, is very much relevant and it's still the case that we discussed in some detail in our Investor Day.

That was it.

A: Thank you, Giles.

So indeed, we see the government sequestration headwind that we're facing as pure timing.
You may recall that overall in our business we have about 50% of our business coming from this customer group and it's spread across many different elements.
And therefore, in the past, in 2013 and also towards the end of 2012, SES did not really see any impact here.

But, of course, now what we see with the passage of time and it's really a timing issue that as we do deal with many individual customers that has contracts and budgets were coming up to the end of the period, we began to see non-renewals.
And so it's - I think it's a normative definition of the fact that there is a time period and now we have this timing impact.
On the other hand, I think what is very important also to remember is the overall SES Government business, the total government business.
Indeed, we have some short-term headwinds in our government services.

But I think it's important to point out that what we've done over the last two to three years is we've also developed a very strong government business in regions outside of the US We've brought in to use in June the second maintenance payload.
We brought in to use last or the first maintenance payload and we've essentially grown this business now to be trending up towards 4% of our overall business.
So from the government point of view, we have a very good balanced portfolio and what we are seeing now is we impacted later and in some cases also to a lesser extent.
And that's as a result of our portfolio and I think that's a timing element rather than anything fundamental.
A: Giles, on the O3b question, you're absolutely right and sort of picking up the messages from Steve, they're quite positive.
I've had the opportunity to meet, interact and, in fact, team up with some of the O3b colleagues on the context of client interactions, whether it was in Africa, Asia or even in Europe.
And every time we had a conversation with the client regarding O3b, and this was followed by an actual live demonstration, the words that were used in this context was a game changer.

And now, what we're doing is, we're in the process through our US government business because this is now a public information to stand up O3b demonstrations to our clients in the US on the government side and these efforts have already started.
Should we sort of revisit our guidance?

And that's the number one priority.
The number two priority is to think through the next generation of the O3b fleet.
As already communicated publicly now by both O3b and Ariane the next batch of satellite 9-12 will be launched by the end of this year on the Hughes rocket.
And once this is done, we're pretty much done with the first generation of O3b satellites.
We need now to particularly think about the next one because on this arc, the new arc that we have filed for, there's still very significant growth potential.
The way we're looking at it, let's go over these priorities, make sure that we address them and then we'll do a sort of reassessment of our guidance.
And when it comes to ASTRA 2G, we pretty much follow what is said in the media and what it confirms is the following is that the satellite has safely reached its destination.
Airbus have confirmed that all is in check.
So now, we're proceeding with all sort of the nominal activities that you would expect.
There were indeed some developments that were unexpected, but these are now behind us.

Are you - can I invite you to take the opportunity to confirm that you can use the insurance proceeds, which I've seen quoted at being $300 million or so, the insurance proceeds on the 41st satellite.
Will you be reinvesting those back into the business?

It's not for us.
But I guess you understand what I think the management would be inclined to do based on the traction that we are seeing now in the marketplace.

O: So we'll now take our next question from Nick Brown from Goldman Sachs.
Please go ahead.
Your line is open.
Q: Thanks.
Three questions, please.
Firstly, should we still expect growth in 2015 to be slower than 2014, given the timing differences you're talking about?

Thanks.
A: Yeah.
So, Nick, I'll take the first one.
You may recall when we gave our guidance back in February, we were very clear in saying that the year with the lowest growth will be in 2015.
There's a number of factors there.
First of all, there will be the sale of four transponders as part of the [Eutelsat] agreement versus the sale of eight this year.

Secondly, if you look at the new launches, so obviously we'll be getting the benefit of ASTRA 2G, but SES-8, which is launched in 2015 with an electronic propulsion, its orbit raising takes a little bit longer.
So if not, projected to, let's say, generate a lot of revenue in 2015.

And so what we see also with the impact of the US government, as we said earlier, we believe while we have very good traction in new business, we probably are being - let's say, we're being cautious here, we're being conservative here, and we then think that the renewal challenge may continue also into the first half of 2015.
So, that's a long answer to say, yes, that we expect 2015 to be lower growth and to be the lowest growth level after three years.
A: Let me take the second question.
So on the - looking at the acquisition part, I think the first opportunity that we're looking at certainly is O3b.
And the question is, within which - what window over the next one to two years in light of the positive developments since the launch of satellite 5-8.
The second priority for us is accelerating the optionalization scale of SES in emerging markets.

And what I mean by that is not just to have satellites that cover these markets, but actually to invest into our local operations whether it's ground infrastructure or actually having people on the ground sort of base there, framing issues, creating these opportunities with clients, as I've described earlier on this call.
This would - may well also include the addition of non-SES assets in selective market, provided that they are complementary within our capability system.
We simply are not going to rush our decision into this.
And so we're continuously looking into these opportunities.
But as I said, there is not going to be any particular rush for us to execute anything.
We have the headroom to do that and both indication of O3b or any other activities whether organic or inorganic in emerging market they would fit within our financial framework.
A: And, Nick, I believe I mentioned SES-8 in terms to launch next year.

It is, of course, SES-9, so SES-8 is up and ramping up nicely but SES-9 goes in the middle of next year with the electronic raising would only start towards the end of the year in terms of the revenue.
Q: Great.
Thanks.

And again, the Global Eagle Entertainment is a case in point where we work very closely with the client to sort of frame their requirements, frame the type of applications and also frame some of the future assets we're going to develop to make sure they're sort of almost sort of custom fit to serve these aeronautical applications.
So, a long answer say, we're not necessarily in the trunking business or in the back-loading business the way others satellite operators.
That is not the SES heritage.
We're also saying that next generation data is important because there are going to be a growing number of reliance on satellite applications.
And this is where we want to sort of make sure that we make a difference and yesterday's announcement is one of those cases.

cost of launch cost, the answer is absolutely yes.

Thanks for the questions.

So the answer to your question is no.
We see growth opportunities in mature as well as in International markets.

And this is reflected in our numbers again in Europe and North America as well as in all International markets.
Padraig, do you want to take over the other two?
A: Yes.

So, Laurie, on the principal components in our share of associates plus from O3b is depreciation, which started in September last year, which is a non-cash item and also the fact that, for this year, the net financing charges have been expensed, and for the first nine months of last year, they were capitalized.

A: No, not necessarily.

And based on the data that is now publicly available for SES, as well as for other satellite operators, and if I take high-definition channels as one data point, our growth year-to-date has been up 18.6% compared to a growth of around 13% for the other satellite operators.

And, again, my observation has to do with our superior performance in that particular area.

O: We will now take our next question from Nick Dempsey from Barclays.
Your line is open.

Q: Hi.

But I know that there would be up-front payments related to hosted payloads in the first half there.
Second question, regarding 2016.
