Are you kind of not saying that anymore, or do we just have to wait and see until February?
Is that a change?
And then the third question is just regarding SES-12, SES-14 and SES-15, your global HTS platform, to what extent does it matter that Intelsat Epic satellite will be up and running before you?
How much of a first-mover advantage will they have?
A: Padraig, why don't you start with the first two questions?
A: Yeah.
So, first of all, Nick, on the - as you know, we don't give precise numbers by verticals.
But what I can say is that for the nine months - what I can confirm is that for the nine months year-to-date, that we continue to see a positive growth trajectory in the government sector.
That's the key message and that's compared to what we've seen in the first six months, we continue to see growth in the government sector.
With respect to the question on 2016, so SES-9 is an important contributor to the 2016 growth.
And essentially, we prefer to wait until the satellite has been launched before providing any further update on the guidance.
With respect to our comment at half year, we were focusing on the underlying growth dynamics.
And here, those growth dynamics, we can confirm that they are still in place.
We're growing in global video.
We have SES-9 coming onboard, adding 53 transponders.
We will have in 2016 the full year benefit of the commercial Ultra HD channels that we signed this year.
Mobility is continuing to grow.
Karim mentioned how our anchor customers double this capacity there.
We'll have the full benefit of that next year.
And also, we have to remember that this year, we've been impacted by the ARSAT migration, the AMC-15/AMC-16 renewals, which won't be in place next year.
So, those growth dynamics continue to be in place.
But now with regards to getting into actual or precise numbers, we plan to do that in February after the launch of SES-9 given its materiality.
A: And so on your question regarding first mover advantage, the answer is, no, there isn't, because it is all a factor of the platforms.
And the two platforms are not comparable.
SES-12, SES-14 and SES-15 have very specific capabilities and are geared towards very specific applications and missions.
And over and above these three programs, we'll benefit from digital-processing-enabled flexibility, which is far more advanced in our industry than what the industry has today.
In fact, in most of the conversation we've had, actually yielded anchor clients that wasn't a sort of a one-on-one competition between the two systems.
They've addressed at different point in time different clients and different segments.
There may be an overlap, but that is not going to be driven by the first-mover advantage thing.

Again, our view is whether the capability are differentiated or not and that was pretty much the center of our focus when we finalized the designs of the three programs and with the other programs that will come in the future.
Q: Great.
Thanks guys.
A: Sure.
O: We will now take our next question from Giles Thorne from Jefferies.
Your line is open.
Please go ahead.
Q: Thank you.
Good morning, guys.
I've got three questions, please.
Starting with the US government, there's been some news flow suggesting that the funding for Pathfinder 2 is progressing well.
That will provide another welcome point - data point to prove the US government's being a bit more flexible and how it works with you guys.
I'd be interested to hear your perspective and how well-positioned SES is to, yet again, be the ultimate winner of this contract.
Obviously, you've got the first Pathfinder a year or so back.
Second question was on - I think its fixed data.
It's picking up on the ARSAT headwind that's been quite prominent.
We had ARSAT 2 launched from the 30th of September.
Should we expect more revenue to be lost for ARSAT 2 once that one comes into service?
And perhaps could you update us on how you see the risk for natural satellite programs in general.
It was a regular topic of conversation a while back, but we haven't heard management commentary in some time.
And lastly, on video, receiving new questions on the role of satellite in developed market TV distribution.
It's certainly a healthy debate we'll be having.
It will be again interesting to hear your perspective on how satellite faces off against the terrestrial alternatives, especially in a world where fiber deployment are ubiquitous.
And when you give your answer, if you could put to one side the debate around this huge cost of making fiber ubiquitous and give us a sense of how you see them face-off against each other directly.
That was it.
Thank you.
A: Okay.
Many interesting questions.
In no particular order, for ARSAT 2, the answer is no.
There's absolutely no relation between the SES business in this particular program.

When it comes to national satellite operators, which I think was your question, it is less relevant for the nature of our business because, increasingly, we're serving global clients, and/or clients that would require coverage across regions that may not be served by the satellite - national satellite operators with whom we will have to interact in these markets or regions.
And thirdly is, we're finally increasing the opportunities to team up with them.
And so I think the industry has come to term with these two different sort of playbooks.
And there is more conversions than sort of confrontation, at least from the perspective of SES.
I think there was a question regarding the US government.
The answer is yes.
I think we're very well-positioned for the second Pathfinder.
In fact, like - what I can share with you is that we continue to be involved in conversation upstream with the US government.

And in the recent conversation, I have to refer, time and again, to the fact that, in this particular market, the approach has to be about orchestrating the opportunities, being involved across the different facets because this is what it takes to translate these opportunities into actual programs.

And as a case in point, during the course of October, our senior SES Government Services colleagues where in interactions with the House and Senate Defense Appropriation Committee, with members of the House Committee on Armed Services with the Subcommittee on Strategic Forces.
And so, we continuously provide a view to the US government on how we can improve the servicing of their requirements.
It is never a question of demand.
It's a matter of how the supplies can be provided within the framework of either the budgeting dynamics or the procurement policies that they have.
And to give due credit, we have found these conversations to be quite open.
And at the end of the day, sort of moving the ball forward in terms of providing flexibility to best serve this client at the end.
And so, I don't expect us not to be able to sort of continue in this pattern.
On sort of the conversation of video delivery, terrestrial versus satellite, this is a very, very healthy debate.
Because at the end, all the markets that we're serving will be better served with hybrid solutions.
No single solution will be a panacea for all the video requirements are increasingly moving from SD to HD and from HD to Ultra HD.
Let me give an example.
If we, in Europe, say today, let's forget about satellite delivery, and let's move everything to fiber.
This will require - you must define the capacity that the network can transport.
So, I'm not talking about the signal reaching the home.
I'm talking about the core and transport method terrestrially.
You will have to modify that 35 times the capacity of the terrestrial network in Europe to be able to deliver video signals, and I am taking Europe as a relatively developed continent.
You will have to sort of multiply by four times the average speed that is delivered today.
And even if you do all of this and you've made the investment, only 54% of the homes will benefit from this.
And we haven't accounted for the cost.
So, let me give me another example.
If the video content is delivered terrestrially, and if you apply the prevailing CDN model which is you pay 0.01 for X bit, whatever that number is, it's a linear relation.
So, you'll see a curve, you total the X and the Y axis, and the curve will go from left to right, in an indefinite manner .
In the satellite word, that cost is fixed, so you'll write - you would draw a fixed line, and, in fact, the intersection is at the point of 2,000 users.
After 2,000 users, every users that you will add will make the terrestrial solution more expansive.
Now, again, this is not a binary conversation.
This is about how you bring the best of both worlds to serve the video applications of the future.
And these are very healthy dialogues.
I have the privilege of meeting with many SES clients, whether it's in Asia, Europe and North America, where I was last week, and I think we're doing all the right things.

I think the wrong thing to do is, again, to sort of take views that are going to be binary which they will do this favor to the end user and certainly we'll do with this favor to the different stakeholders in the industry.
Q: All right, Karim.
Thank you.
O: We will now take your next question, Sami Kassab from Exane.
Your line is open.
Please go ahead.
Q: Thank you very much.
Good morning, everybody.

First, you talked about positive momentum in fixed data in Q3, could you elaborate on that please and perhaps tell us if you had seen more customers returning fixed data capacity in that quarter or not?
Secondly and perhaps coming back to Giles' and your comment on video broadcasting.
If possible, can you comment on the difference in the marginal cost for video broadcasting on satellite versus terrestrial infrastructure and possibly just the marginal cost, not the total cost?
And lastly, can you elaborate on your views regarding consumer Internet broadband access?
I believe, historically, this was not a core focus of SES strategy.
On the other hand, you had successes with the UK and German pilots.
So do you think there is a big opportunity there after all?
Thank you, Karim.
A: Thank you.
So on data, there are two dynamics.
One is we have to address the currency fluctuation and appreciation and the commercial team and the finance team have done an extraordinary job over the past six months.
And we were able to sort of de-risk to a great extent that particular headwind.

The positive dynamic, which is equally important for me, is that I see increase in the SES being involved in national digitization programs, whether it's about e-learning, connecting government agencies, enabling literally national election in very prominent African countries.

Recently, SES was awarded, in a mature market, a very important program on multiple transponders, not yet communicated publicly, to connect their remote areas, and this is probably one of the largest that we have achieved.
And that for me is the kind of sustainable model that you want to have in the long term.

This does not, in any way, undermine the importance of the smaller data-centric engagements in emerging market, but it simply means that we have to sort of expand our uptake beyond the sort of legacy business and ask the question, can we be central and - can we play a relevant and sustainable growth in the digital sort of national initiatives?
And, increasingly, I'm seeing that the answer is yes, which is why I've made the statement that I see a positive momentum.
This is not to say that all is peaches and cream.
We still have to be very adaptive in that particular segment, the same way that I've mentioned that in the coupling business.
It's all about orchestrating the opportunity.

In the data fixed market, it is all about having a very adaptive approach to make sure that you set up your pace, your go-to market approach with the dynamics innovations with the national market, and interplay with the alternative technology.
So, the question of alternative technology in my mind is nothing [indiscernible] .
And the more you take a view that it has to be integrated, I think the better your performance is going to be.
When it comes to consumer broadband, so, indeed, we have various targets and initiatives, where we believe that we have differentiated offering.
UK is one of them.
We have similar programs in France, in Switzerland, in Germany and in some parts of Africa and the Middle East.
And we're very committed to these specific programs.
SES, by design, does not have a strategy for mass consumer broadband.
At the end, we are pursuing a forefront strategy which is focused on video, fixed data, mobility and government.
And this is really how we're focusing our resources.
Is there a market in consumer broadband, mass consumer broadband, the way it's being talked about across the ICT industry?
The answer is absolutely yes.
In our view, there are alternative technologies to serve that market.
But certainly, we're taking a view within SES as well as with O3b, because this is equally important, that we are best positioned to serve the B2B market.
And so when there's a discussion about serving consumer VOD end market over satellites, there are, today, two successful models, both of them are in North America.
There could be other successful models in the future, it's yet to be seen.
There have been discussion around delay of installations which are single-mindedly focused on this.
And you know my question around this, so I don't think the answer is yes or no.
I think it's a matter of how the technology, the operation, the regulations and, ultimately, the economics will enable this.
So, for us, there is a market in mass consumer broadband.
This is not for SES.
We've made a deliberate choice to focus our resources elsewhere, and so that we can sort of succeed in what we have elected to do.
And my sense is, this is a space that is yet to be defined around a single industry.
I think multiple industries will continue to serve it.
It's probably one of the most competitive segments in our view, and does sort of influence, to a great extent, our thought process around this market opportunity.
On video, I think your question has to do with whether we'll continue to see the interplay between the different technology and the answer is absolutely yes.
Now - and I've already expressed my view on how this is going to play out.
It's not binary.

What excites me a lot is the fact that whether you look at mature market as well as international markets, the amount of time per date, per week, per month, whatever you want to use it, per user, in terms of video consumption is going up.
Even in the case of linear, it is stable to going up.
Of course, the non-linear is increasing at a faster pace, but it remains a fraction of the total prime that is being used.
And because of that, we see tremendous opportunities.
Now, what is interesting - and I think I've shared this either on this call or a similar forum - when we meet with clients now, the conversation is not anymore about a single mode type of delivery.
It's about how can you, SES, help us in getting across the multiple modes of deliveries, which is something that we're already doing in a number of our markets.

And time and again, we're seeing the ability to sort of scale this video experience, scale it up, both in terms of the breadth and depth of the business that we're serving, the number of channels that we'll be carrying, and ultimately the number of people we're reaching.

I mean by the end of the day, if we're reaching today - by the end of 2014, if we're reaching 312 million households, that would equate to 1.1 billion, 1.2 billion individuals who, in some shape or form, are enjoying their video experience because of SES.
That is not an insignificant number.
And certainly, my ambition is that we want to go much farther than this.
But you're only going to do this if we take the hybrid approach and we walk away from the legacy sort of binary this system or that system.
That update is obsolete.
I hope I've answered your questions.
Q: Thank you very much, Karim.
O: We will now take our next question from [indiscernible] from Ironshield Capital.
Your line is open.
Please go ahead.
Q: Good morning and thank you for taking my question.
A couple of them, actually.
So, first of all, could you give us a bit more granularity on pricing?
So, how have you seen your pricing either per megahertz or per transponder developing over the past couple of quarters and the last quarter?
And how do you see these pricing dynamics might be changed when more of the global capacity has migrated to high throughput?
And also, how you see yourself competing with a number of fewer Ka-band players out there, especially the Middle East and Africa?
And also, if you could comment on - in your presentation in September, when you showed where your HTS capacity's going to be deployed, I have seen that you haven't really covered much of the Africa.
So, again, what is the key driver behind making this decision?
Is it like that there's no market there or it's too competitive or this is just something that you believe is less of an opportunity than the other regions?
Thank you.
A: So, let me take the pricing question and then Africa.
On pricing, you have to look at it by market vertical.
And video, which represents 70% of our business today, the pricing is driven by a single unit, which is your technical reach.
And given the SES posture in that beam, pricing has been pretty much fixed.

In fact, in many markets, the formula where - I would qualify as sort of developing our international market, the formula is working with a view that as our technical reach increases, the pricing improves.
Because, ultimately, you're providing higher value to your customer.
In the mobility segment, this is a segment that has been unfolding particularly in an erratic way over the past two years to three years, we've seen a phenomenal acceleration.
The pricing was a different nature because now the price increasingly is being defined down to the level of the end-user experience, i.e., the traveler, or at the level of the airplane.
So, the unit obviously is different.
And the higher the performance is, the better you're in a position to monetize the connectivity that you're providing and the overall solution around it.
And there, we have developed our HTS fleet to be deployed in 2016 and 2017 to do that.
And in the meantime, we're using our wide beam fleet to be able to deliver this.
So, these programs were designed with particular payloads in mind, with specific economic and price points which all fit within our financial framework.
But again, these are very different payloads for very specific applications.
In fixed data, I think we talked about this during the first half.
And increasingly, we're putting emphasis on either national programs and/or planned regional or multi-region programs.
Case in point is our agreement with Airbus for providing fixed data solutions across Africa.
And there, the relationship's not just the pricing per transponder, but it's all about a network management solution.
And what this does, it sort of immediately creates a platform for value add.
So you don't fall into the dynamic of I get per unit this and you have to match that.
You literally eliminate this.
And finally, in government, there are two sides of the government business.
There is a side where there is a one-to-one purchase of capacity which still has some prevalence.
But also, there is a big part of the government which has to deal with end-to-end solution.
And because of that again, the dynamic of pricing per transponder to a great extent is mitigated whether this price is going up or down.
It does happen in some cases where the government is simply buying capacity.
SES Government Services is one of the very few entities that, A, is sanctioned and, B, is capable of delivering end-to-end solutions.
For Africa, we're not taking a view on sort of whether be it the dynamics are favorable at a macro level.
What I can tell you is what we see as SES in this market.
In the case of video, we are short of capacity to be able to sort of further expand.
And case in point, I think, Padraig, was the latest satellite that we have put there, which now is fully utilized.
And we've developed very sort of nice and differentiated neighborhood, whether they are French-speaking or English-speaking or different dialects and languages.
So, depending on the market verticals that we choose to sort of serve and we focus on, we have seen very positive dynamics in Africa.
I certainly can't speak on behalf of the other satellite operators and other dynamics to which we are not exposed.

And time and again, I would caution in this conversation the sort of the - sometimes, the inclination of sort of averaging Africa as a troubled region or Latin America or Asia or Europe or what have you.
Time and again, the challenge for us is to de-average each and every market and say, what is positive?
What is the trend?
What is dynamic per market verticals and how you can differentiate?
And if you do that right, and I would like to think we're doing this right, then you're going to end up with a positive outcome.
Q: Thank you.
And a quick follow-up on this, if I may.

Going back to the pricing point, when you compare the new contracts you might be signing with different types of the clients, how do you see those contracts differ from the contracts you already have or you had signed, say, about five years ago?
I mean, do you see them either the pricing itself or the thinking about pricing itself to other pricing mechanics trending?
So, if you comment on the average duration of this contract, is it still around 10 years, 15 years or we are talking about shorter periods?
Thank you.
A: Well, one dynamic that we get to that, I get to see at the Executive Committee.
I wouldn't claim that I am the market leader today , but the one that I see is quite interesting.
Either contracts are renewed in a comparable manner, or you have a dynamic where the contract could be of a shortened nature, but the pricing is associated to a premium.
Or there's a longer period, but then there's a pricing advantage that is provided to the client.
And so, there isn't a single formula that you can apply over here.
But we're saying that for different type of clients, the formula works in a way that either fits their economics or actually fits their view about what are their priorities going forward.
So recently, with one of our largest clients in the international market, there was a pickup of new capacity.
And this was done at more favorable economics, but the backlog was significantly more expanded.
And [indiscernible] , there were cases where new capacity was added on shorter runways than previous mandates.
But the economics were of a different nature, i.e., less favorable.
And I think we have to be flexible in each and every market condition.
Padraig, you want to add something?
A: Yeah.
I would say maybe just to put at a very macro level some color on it financially.
I mean, if you do very simple calculation, and again, as Karim said many times, we position ourselves as offering a different tier of service.
And operating a different tiered service means we're selling capacity and we're selling services with that.

So, if you do a simple calculation, you look at how our revenues have been developing over the last nine months, or you look how our utilized transponders are, and you calculate an average rate, you see pricing is holding up very well.
And I think it's flat to down on 2%.
But when you consider that against what's happening and where we're growing, and then look at what's happening in the average cost per transponder year, this is all a very favorable dynamic.

And the key differentiation for SES is we're able to perform like that because we're not in the business of selling transponder capacity, we're in the business of providing differentiated solutions to our customers.

And I think that's one, I've said that before, that's one good indicator to look at, is just take our total revenue and you can then, including your services, back into an average price and you see that that performance as very, very robustly.
Q: Okay.
Thank you.
And last question, on the cost side, with the new satellites being launched, how should we think about increasing your fixed and variable OpEx?
A: In general, we have an objective that new programs would have to be - Martin, I think, said last year, 20% more efficient, and that applies both to CapEx and OpEx.

And when you get into the next-generation satellites which in the case of SES has wide beams as well as narrower high throughput beams, as we start laying down the sort of the landing points and the rest of the infrastructure, once you pass a certain scale, you immediately start having the advantage of economies of scale with that terrestrial network, which is a point that we're going to get post SES-15.
So, in a sense, I would sort of expand that 20% both for the CapEx as well as the OpEx and we're well underway.
I think Martin has reported in our Investor Day that we are past the 10% improved efficiency in CapEx and OpEx.
A: Correct.
And maybe just to add, essentially - we are essentially a fixed cost model.
Of course, if you look at our total model with services in the platforms, there's a degree of variability there.
But overall, I think that on the OpEx side, you'll see that over the years, our OpEx is remaining relatively flat.

And the biggest cost we have is below the EBITDA line and what you've been seeing there is you've been seeing that our normalized CapEx, the cost per transponder year, although we have targeted to reduce this by 20% between 2014 and 2018, and as we outlined in our Investor Day, we've already delivered 12 percentage points of the 20 percentage points.
And so, that's going in the right direction.
Q: Okay.
Thank you very much.
O: We will now take our next question from Sachin Gula from Credit AM .
Please go ahead, sir.
Q: Hello, gentlemen.
Thanks for taking my questions.
First one is really a simple and open one.
It's about substitution.

Is the rollout of the fiber in the more developed area like Europe and North America will become substitute or is already competing with your geostationary offer for the fixed data and video market vertical?
Or is it too different and it doesn't address the same needs?
A: I'm sorry.
Let me try to rephrase the question to make sure I understand it.
Q: Yeah.
Sure.
A: So, your question if fiber is deployed in...
Q: If it will become substitute at some point compared to your geostationary offer, what you offer actually for fixed data and video for Europe and North America.
Because I understood for O3b it's different because you don't have such kind of infrastructure, so that's why you call it fiber in the sky.
But now in Europe, since we have a massive rollout of this fiber, is it becoming, at some point, a substitute to your offer with what you have with this?
A: I get your question.
So, let me start with the data one.
So, when it comes to data services in Europe and North America, they may be of two nature.
One may be mobility and there, terrestrial is not relevant.
And increasingly, we're seeing mobility applications, whether this has to do with commercial mobility or defense-related mobility.
And increasingly, in the defense space, there would be emphasis on autonomous distance, whether they are terrestrial systems or aeronautical systems or maritime system.
And so in that particular vein, we see a continuity of the relevance and differentiation of satellite.

And again, this is why I've made the statement SES had made a deliberate choice not to sort of try to address at a mass level the consumer broadband segment, because that is a segment where terrestrial fixed or terrestrial mobile is progressing in an industry that I have served in my previous life for more than 15 years.

When it comes to video, our view - our experience today and our view of the next five years and beyond is we're increasingly operating in a hybrid moment, because as you move from SD to HD and from HD to Ultra HD, terrestrial systems will be very challenged to be able to do all the heavy lifting.
The numbers I gave earlier on the call, as an example, we're just taking a sort of a, everything from satellite to terrestrial all based on HD.

And in Ultra HD environment, you have to visualize that networks will have to be dimension not just in terms of access, but in terms of the core network being able to carry the capacity and store it and deliver it by 100 times, by 100 times.
So, if you have to take the CapEx today and multiply literally by 100 for the core fiber part of the network.
Q: Okay.

A: And even if you do that, because you will not be able to grow fiber across the board, if you try to sort of say I want these fixed solutions, At the end, only 20% of household in a continent like Europe will be able to deliver that.
And again, it's very difficult for me having spent 15 years in the telecom industry and now have the privilege of working in the satellite industry.
I probably have a first feed - first to have seen to be able to sort of say, there is going to be hybrid solution at the end of the day, because even within the terrestrial world, there is a debate.
Is the future going to be fixed or is the future going to be mobile?
And within mobile, is the future going to be over wireless networks or is it going to be enabled to a great extent by Wi-Fi systems, mesh system across cities and what have you.
And for me, these debates have existed since 2005 production of the first iPhone.
So, time and again, the markets have proven that they are going to require the best combination of the available technology; terrestrial, fixed, mobile, other wireless forms and satellites.
And that combination will continue to evolve.
So, there is no formula today that we're going to fix.
Each one of them will continue to play an instrumental role, because if you try to do this in one area, that is not going to have results.
And let me give you another example to let you understand what I'm talking about it.
We are using the Ku band to provide broadcasting across the world, directly DTH, unless we are providing cable bandwidth services like we do in North America.
We use 2 gigahertz.
That is the band that is provided to our industry.
On that 2 gigahertz, we carry 75 exabytes per month.
That is what we do.
The I&C world of mobile industry has 1 gigahertz, and they carry month-in, month-out around 1.5 exabytes.
So if you just did a video as a stress test, we're 25 times more efficient to carry a video than the wireless network.
So even if people can say, wireless network are cheaper and faster to deploy, they cannot substitute satellite.
And it's the same thing.
Satellites cannot substitute the role and the functionality of a wireless network.

So time and again, we're looking at analysis and our experiences that are demonstrating in the medium to long term and in the present, I'll be sort of coming together, hybrid networks of net position to serve end users.
Q: Okay.
A: I hope this made a point or reason for you.
Q: Yeah.
That's helpful.
Thank you.
And maybe another one on O3b.

Since you're already addressing, for example, Latin America with your satellites, is O3b will somehow cannibalize some of your fixed data because from what I understood, O3b is mostly figured that out for those kind of remote area.
So would it be more complementary or will you see some maybe overlap within your geostationary offer and O3b?
A: The answer is much more complementary than anything else.
So take where O3b today has the largest footprint in the Pacific Island.
The solution they require cannot provide - cannot be provided over our satellites today.
And so O3b has done a phenomenal job.
In fact, just after barely 12 months of operation, they're the largest connectivity provider to this part of the world.
We're talking about communities of millions and millions of inhabitants.

Even if Latin America where we were aiming to provide solution to mobile network operators depending on where you are providing that service at which point of the network for what type of quality of service that there's a perfect complementarities between the two fleets.

Now, my wish in the future is that this kind of understanding will become clearer and clearer in the marketplace, and as SES moves from its position today in the capital of O3b into a controlling position, we will be, I think, in a position to sort of accelerate that understanding and bring these benefits much faster to the different regions.
Q: Okay.

And just last one question, it's about the newcomer with the LEO low-orbital satellite, what kind of threat do you see from them and maybe if they are able to address all the four market verticals that you have, it will be different or will be in direct competition with you?
A: Yeah.
So, I can only refer to the public discourse around these programs, and the key position product for consumer broadband.
And as I've said on this call, that is not a segment that we're targeting within our four market growth pillars.
Q: Okay.
Thank you.
A: And again, these constellations are work in progress.
There are different levels of commitment, and the answer to the four questions that I raised whether it's for LEO, MEO or GEO, which is how the technology work, how this operates [indiscernible] ?
How the regulatory model looks?
But having said that, we're sort of observing this closely.
And so the impact on us is - we don't see a direct impact again because it's in a market that we've elected not to serve directly.

It doesn't mean that a GEO operator cannot be successful in that market, but because of great strategic sort of reasons, that is the choice of something we've elected not to do unless we can bring the differentiator particularly for specific national programs and the successes that SES has had in Europe are cases in point.
Q: Okay.
Thank you very much.
O: We will now take our next question from Nick Brown from Goldman Sachs.
Your line is open.
Please go ahead.
Q: Thank you.
If I can also follow up on Giles' fiber question.

In Spain, where you have a contract, there's been a lot of fiber investment, and Telefonica's actively migrating satellite customers onto its IPTV platform because they can offer broadband speeds more than four times faster, and capacity threshold network has increased a lot.
Is it really realistic to think they will keep paying the same for satellite capacity going forward if it's servicing a significantly lower number of customers?
A: Well, the answer is that is a relation we have with them.
Telefonica is a client of SES across the world.
And so, in different markets, there are going to be different dynamics.
So, so far in Spain, we've had a very constructive relation with them.
We've been serving very well their market.
As I said before there may be some substitution, there may be development areas in other parts of Spain.
And so, I continue to take a view and the market is certainly telling us that the goal opportunities and the better opportunities are yet to come for us and for these clients.
Q: Okay.
Thanks.
A: And in the not-so-distant future, I'm going to be in Spain.
Q: Thanks.

And have you seen the new G.fast and Vplus Super Vectoring DSL technology which will bring a big a ramp-up in speeds and capacity at terrestrial broadband networks in Europe in the next couple of years?
Won't this mean in some countries, including some of your largest markets, that there will be a viable alternative for linear video broadcasting?
A: Yeah.
Yeah.
So, I've read with interest your paper, and I thought some of the cases that were mentioned were projects I've worked on in my previous life.
This is a technology that has been around sort of discussed for quite some time.
And as you rightly noticed, it brings significant enhancements in the case of short distances.
But like any other rollout of technology, it's going to take time, it's going to take clearances, and it's going to take some costs.

And I think some of the questions that will be raised is whether policymakers would want the incumbents to go in that direction or they would want to - they would want them to sort of - if they're going to make an investment whether it's going to be fiber, like or not.
The second one is that as you deploy these, you're addressing primarily the question of providing sort of easy connectivity at the level of the household or whatever that unit is.
You haven't yet answered the question around the other elements of the network, which you would need to scale.

And so, as you go through all of this thought process, there is always going to be a trade-off in the mind of the CEO, the CEO on the telecom side is - whether this is the decision that they would want to pursue or whether there's going to be trade-off without driving the technology, because remember, there's also - if you were the incumbent, so you have fixed and mobile network.
It's a zero sum game.
You have to invest in that thing and you have to still invest in fiber and you have to invest in 4G sort of ubiquity and 5G, which would be coming in the next few years.
And so, that is not new.
That's the dynamic that we continue to experience.
In a sense, it may improve the IPTV experience in some of the markets where IPTV is already present.
But it is unlikely to be the ubiquitous sort of connectivity for all the areas that we're serving with our satellite system.

And because of that and as we move up from SD to HD and the percentage of shares earlier accelerating as we accelerate the introduction of Ultra HD, I think there is going to be a very nice complementary between satellite, the technology that we refer to, as well as the other terrestrial-based technology that are coming offline because you can make the argument for any other new technology.
In my sense, this will be in a better place if we take the uptick of the hybrid network.
Q: That's great.
Thank you.
A: We'll take one last question now please, Priscilla.
O: Thank you.
Our final question comes from Paul Sidney from Credit Suisse.
Your line is open, sir.
Please go ahead.
Q: Thank you very much.
Good morning.
Just two questions to finish with, please.
Just expanding the video discussion.
You signed many Ultra HD contracts over the past six months.

I was just wondering whether you could share with us any detailed feedback from the broadcasters about the potential for them to expand the number of channels on UHD and sort of further embrace the technology.
And then just secondly, just a very sort of broad, general question.
We've seen all the satellite operators, the big global satellite operators generally hitting numbers this week and reiterating guidance.
I was just wondering, in your opinion, do you think the environment for global satellite has stabilized?
Do you think we're over some of the headwinds that have affected the industry over the last couple of years and we're now heading into hopefully a lot more positive stable environment?
Thank you.
A: Thank you.
So, I think for HD, I think there are two interesting dynamics.

One which I've shared with my board and I think I've mentioned this during the Investor Day is, when we look at international markets, so outside North America and Europe, what I was very pleased with my visit Ultra HD meeting with clients is they're already thinking about sort of an Ultra HD world.
And so the gap, the lag in sort of adopting new technology is shrinking increasingly.
In fact, some of the channels that we have announced merchant channels, have coverage beyond the confines of our mature markets.
So, that is interesting.
Now, it doesn't mean we're there.
But the key part of that we managed to break the sort of the glass or literally the cement ceiling on the introduction of Ultra HD is going to pay for the acceleration.
In the mature markets, the many sort of CEOs and CTOs have met particularly on the broadcaster side, the comment was this has come a bit faster in some parts.
And there is still sort of the onus on them to see how they can scale up parts of their operation to get there.
Now, that scale up is, in many cases, for these broadcaster, it's much easier to achieve than if you were entertaining an alternative technology.
So, I think the dynamic is - the dynamic that will be experienced in Ultra HD is going to create an acceleration in sort of the commercial rollout of the new Ultra HD channels.

And as a case in point, the fact that we are being quite successful in accelerating the SD to HD transition, which I've always said is a segue to upgrading to a higher video experience, all this sort of works very well for what we intend to do on Ultra HD.
And again, we're probably one year ahead of when we thought we were going to break that glass or cement ceiling.
So, my sense is we need to stay the course.
I need to sort of caution everyone's understanding after this.
To be successful in Ultra HD is not just about having a transponder and then - it's about providing a sort of a technical solution end to end.
And in fact, we were successful particularly because of that.

When it comes to sort of the view of the industry and what have you, I truly appreciate this question because it sort of allows me to emphasize time and again that we need to de-average the industry from sort of a satellite and ex-transponder to sort of the dynamic in each and every market segment.
So, in video, I can only speak on behalf of SES, we still see significant growth opportunities.

And if I factor out the impact of the Eutelsat agreement of last year and partly this year, we'll have quite a significant and impressive growth, and again, we translate this to channel and what have you.
And there, it's about how you develop economies of scale and how do you expand your technical reach on the solution behind it.
In fixed data, you need to be much more agile and adjusted than what the [indiscernible] have been in the past.
If you can do that, you can be successful.
It doesn't mean that it's all peaches and cream.
You are going to hit some bumps here and there because this is where you have the most intensive Ultra HDR platform technology, and it's focused on the right sort of programs, it's quite rewarding.
Mobility is about being quite disciplined and seeing how far this thing can go, whether it's about the experience on airline or a boat or a sort of cruise ship?

If you think that in pre-September 2014, the experience on a cruise ship was 20 or 30 megabit per second for thousands of traveler, and today, it's a multiple of hundreds of megabits depending on what the ships have contracted in O3b.
You've created a new market that didn't exist.
We're doing the same thing in avionics, and we still have a long way to go.
In Government, I think there are two different dynamics.
There is a US government, and what we all know very well and I've already described.
But often, the other question that we wish to raise is, what about the other sort of NATO-related governments?
And if they were to adopt a defense strategy that is comparable to the one of the US, how does this translate into a market or satellite-enabled connectivity and solution?

And to give one example, the UAV connectivity over satellite is today a $300 million market.
If you take the top 20 nations and you take out India and other large nations from the equation because they can sort of create a bias on the equation.

So, if the 20 other nations have a defense strategy that's comparable to the US in terms of unmanned systems, bot-piloted systems, that $300 million becomes a $1.5 billion, $1.6 billion market in today's technology.
So, there is still a lot of things to do.
So, there may not be - that is the type of things that we're doing today.
But certainly, the best opportunities still lie ahead of us, if we have sort of that vision to pursue them.

It's probably - it's great know - well, I noticed that you're now below 3 times leverage and set to de-lever quickly from here, while at the same time, you're quite comfortable with letting Hellas Sat pass, at least detach early potential - at least potentially early signals of a less pro-investments and more pro-shareholder friendly uses of cash policy.

A: Okay, Giles, so maybe I think your two first questions, I will kind of - probably I have to disappoint you regarding the quality of the response regarding the first question on India.

And that will develop our business, both for the outsourcing business with companies like EchoStar, but also the demand for capacity on our cable [indiscernible] So all in all, maybe - at least, let me - to put it in a very prudent way; our forecast for US market has not been revised negatively.

A: For the third question, Andrew.

So for this year, indeed, that will be a pretty substantial use of all of our cash.
So really, in 2014 is where indeed our CapEx - as we see our CapEx profile, will indeed start to come down.

And I think what Romain has said is that while we sort of highlight that now, it's something we've been speaking about over the last number of years and now, indeed, that in fact is coming to pass with our discipline and understanding.

And then, just to remind that we've always said consistently, any spare cash or uses that we have is indeed for any potential new organic growth opportunities that might come that would make sense to give us good returns, looking at potential M&A opportunities going forward, that indeed, and thereafter looking to shareholder returns.
Q: But just a follow-up.

Q: Hi, everyone.

I understood the part on the cost of manufacturing, but what was the first part of that?

A: Yes, okay.
So I'll take your second question first, and then Andrew will take your first question.
On the SES-6, so we obviously are looking at diversification of the launch vehicles.
We have long-term multiple launch agreements in place with ILS for Proton and for Arianespace with Ariane.
We have always been quite innovative when it came to the selection of launch vehicles.
We were in 1996, the first Westbound satellite operator ever to launch a satellite on - a Western-built satellite on the Russian Proton in [indiscernible] .
So our team clearly identified SpaceX with Falcon 9 in the larger version that will be used for the launch of SES-6.
It's really a next step in the development of launch vehicles in terms of quality and also in terms of price quality relationship.
And so, we went for it.
Since then, we have signed another contract with three launches now, and that is for Falcon 9 or for Falcon Heavy.
And we are looking forward to this first launch.
It will be the second launch in this configuration, meaning with a larger pairing and also with a more powerful engine.
The first launch would be done with a Canadian science satellite, I think, in a month or two.
And then we will be on the launch pad normally in June for the launch of SES-6.

So what is also interesting is that we see, beyond this first launch on Falcon, also the very efficient combination of all-electric propulsion satellites with launches like Falcon 9, for example, a stacked launch, where you put two satellites together, you separate the two satellites together, and then they separate from each other in space.
And we see all-electric propulsion orbit raising done by satellite itself.
You can have a quite dramatic reduction in the CapEx costs for the launch of the satellite by combining quite innovative technology both on the launcher side and also satellite manufacturing side.
A: And just to address your first question, you look at the overall guidance, 2012 to 2014, which is consistent with which we said at this time 12 months ago of approximately sort of 4.5%.

Pricing has indeed been stable, so we don't anticipate any particular changes in pricing.
And I think it is true services businesses, indeed, over time, historically have been increasing as a relative percentage of our overall business.
And that trend most likely will, indeed, continue with continued good development of HD+.
So all of these factors are playing in.

And then in specific - specifically to the - looking at the switch-off of analogue, we had 13 transponders that had we contracted initially with the switch-off, that will indeed have contributed to 2012.
So when you look at those baskets of drivers, that's the explanation.

A: Hi, Giles.
Maybe to start with your last question first.
So SES-10 will be in very good orbit position 67 west, so it's in the sweet arc for servicing Latin America.
That's one strong aspect of it.
Second, as we have clearly stated in the press release, it is done in collaboration with the Andean community.
So there is the support of those four countries of the Andean community who will also use this satellite for different applications to their citizens.
Third point is this satellite which is not a greenfield approach 67 west today is already operated with SES-3 and SES-4.
If I remember correctly, we had something like 34, 35 satellites currently available in several position, and as we say in the presentation, SES-10 will add the number 27.
So this is not an investment where we have to start our business from scratch.
This is a business already existing today and that will continue to grow based on the capacity available until the arrival of SES-10, acquisition of additional capacity from this new satellite.
So we are very confident that this satellite will be a very strong asset for providing services in the Latin American market.

On your question on Telefonica, so clearly this is a kind of application O3b will also serve, but in the absence of O3b being available, it's clear that geostationary satellite solutions are used, and so that's why this is something that we provide with C-band on geostationary satellite, but definitely O3b is in discussions with telcos in the same region, in the same markets to provide this mobile backhauling services with O3b satellites as soon as those satellites will become available.

And on the first question regarding the change in the US government satellite procurement policies, so we continue to lobby together with other satellite operators and satellite industry players but obviously we have to wait until this is really technically translate into reality.

And having said this, we have foreseen in 2013 flat revenue development from the government business and we foresee positive development in 2014, and as we had the business of SES government solutions plus the business that we do with institutions outside of US and there, for example, the fact that we added EGNOS one payload on ASTRA 2E in 2013 and we will add the second payload on ASTRA 5B, the second EGNOS payload, and this will become available with the launch of ASTRA 5B at the end of the first quarter.
And so all of this will have to grow our government business.

Maybe I'll respond to you by simply repeating what I said over a year ago is, when we decided to invest in O3b, we were looking at what revenue would be at risk in SES once O3b would be up and running and became something like $50 million.

And so over time, with O3b being launched and really developing commercial services, you might have an impact of these kinds on the SES number unload in a year but spread over years and compared to the impact O3b will have on our competitors and the impact on SES is obviously very small and that's, by the way, the reason why we invested in O3b at the time.

Thanks.

Why do you think we should have confidence that these estimates will be met, and why have you over-exaggerated the growth in the industry before?
Thanks.
A: Okay, Laurie.
Maybe I'll ask Padraig obviously to comment maybe on each of these questions.
I would simply want to make two remarks.
On the last one you ended by saying that we would have overestimated growth in the industry.
The growth in the industry that we shared with you was 3% CAGR.
So clearly, when we guide to 4%, 4.5%, when we guide to 6% to 7% in 2014, the asset is well above the average of the industry.
That's very clear.
And so we are confident that we will be able to meet those guidance both for 2014 and for the CAGR 2014, 2016.
On MPEG-2 to MPEG-4 conversion, we have included, obviously, in our business plan and thus also for the period we guide through our assumptions regarding our customers' move from MPEG-2 to MPEG-4.

So you can take it for granted that based on our knowledge and because of our, I would say, strategic relationship with our last customers, we are quite well informed about their plans and we will not be taken by surprise when they will switch from MPEG-2 to MPEG-4.
You will understand that we cannot share with you the information that we have regarding timing of our main customers regarding the switch from MPEG-2 to MPEG-4.
A: Yes, and perhaps, Laurie, just some more color in terms of the number.
So, starting with the guidance and the confidence in the guidance.

So, the first thing I would say on that is with respect to 2013 we adjusted due to the launch delays, which doesn't have an IRR impact and we're coming in now pretty much within the range that we guided.

Secondly, I think it's also important to look not only at the CAGR between 2011 and 2014, or as we call it 2012 to 2014, but also if you look at the CAGR excluding the analog impact, which would have been quite material in 2011.

And if you look at that, you'll actually see that - or if you take the current growth rate that we're projecting into 2014, you'll see a 7% CAGR excluding analog, which compares to 7.5% we gave back in 2011.
And you'll actually see an 8% EBITDA CAGR which compares to the 8% EBITDA CAGR we gave back in 2011.
So, we must remember that in the last three years, the last three to four years, the analog reversion has been having quite an important growth suppression effect on the SES numbers.
And even looking now at 2013, with revenue growth of 5.9%, all this seems reasonably - should seem very credible going forward because you have to back out analog.
Maybe one other element to look at in terms of the question around compression.

If you actually look at our results in 2013 and you see the 12% channel growth, but you really have to look at that channel growth again because it's essentially coming in the European and in the international market.

And, again, if you look at Europe growing at 6%, excluding the analog impact, and if you look at international growing at 12.8%, channel is growing at 12%, and you consider that the channel growth, quite a lot of this came in the second half of the year as we brought SES-6 online, as we brought the new satellites online, you see all that ties up very nicely in terms of additional channels in video driving additional top line revenue.
And so, I think that's just some more background as to how we see the guidance and the related numbers.
Q: And the earnings points, the earnings mix?
A: Yes.
So we don't give specifics earnings per region.

But what we can say is that you can consider that, for example, overall margins in the international markets are actually quite strong because even though the average price per transponder is lower, the satellites tend to be much larger, which in turn give a lower average price per transponder.

A: So, Dimitri, to start off with your last question first, I think we have said this in the past already, and that's the criteria you are using is the right one.
So obviously, we are looking for acquisition opportunities mainly in regions of the world where we do not have good raw material ourselves, meaning orbital positions and frequency rights.

And we had very good orbital positions, as for example, showing now with SES-10 at 67 West and SES-6 at 40.5 West for Latin America and North America, needless to say that we have a lot of orbital positions there.

Europe, Middle East and Africa, we have also very strong neighborhoods and in the different agreements we signed, we see that we clearly further consolidated our frequency spectrum that's available in that region for growth in existing satellites and on future satellites.
So the region where this is not true to some extent is Asia Pacific.
And so if there's any region and profitable acquisition in the infrastructure business might make sense, it's definitely in this Asia-Pacific region.

On the price per transponders, your first question, you will see the price per transponder, the average price per transponder of the SES fleet decreasing because we are adding more capacity in the emerging markets where definitely, we are not generating the same revenue level as we do in Europe with DTH positions on our very valuable orbital positions.
So simply because of the weighting between capacity in Europe and outside of Europe, we will see the average price per transponder decreasing.
Having said this, we see that price is in the different markets remaining stable.
Once again, we always said, with the exception of Africa.

When it's about using the Ku-band for video in Africa, their prices also still quite good and stable.
So it's the only market where we see decreasing prices are Africa for non-video and - sorry, I forgot to mention is Eastern Europe as it is definitely a market where there is over capacity.
So with those exceptions, prices are stable and average price per transponder on our fleet simply goes down for weighting reasons.
Padraig, O3b impact in 2014?

A: Okay.
So, Sarah, on all electric propulsion satellite, so you know we are using electric propulsion on satellite, for example, SES-10, we'll also have electric propulsion called station-keeping.
But all electric satellites we are doing the Electra development program together with OHB and the European Space Agency.
This is development programs where there is a total cost of 12 million obviously coming mainly from the ESA and national budgets.
And we will decide at the end of this development phase whether the Electra platform is commercially attractive in order to invest into a satellite carrying such a platform.

In parallel, obviously, we'll continue to discuss with all the other satellite manufacturers who are also developing and offering all-electric satellite platforms, and so this will be as usually request for proposals and SES will go for technically and commercially best solutions.
On the Eutelsat frequency coordination, so we definitely, with this have two times 500 megahertz of capacity that we can use over Europe half and the other half outside of Europe.
So it's the same capacity levels that we use.

When you asked the question about the overall impact, that maybe Padraig wants to go into more details, but in two or three sentences, the different elements are such that there are commercial agreements.

Then there is a second component, which is an commercial agreement on the transponders, eight transponders Eutelsat can use in the disputed frequencies, in the disputed German frequencies, and the contract where revenues will come in over the life of the contract.
So that's the commercial part of it.

And then when it's about frequency coordination, that's obviously from our side an enhancement of the intangible assets that we are using and from an accounting perspective, you find this in intangible assets and Padraig, we are depreciating this over the life of the license?
A: Correct.
It will be depreciated over various long-term periods based on the different licenses.
A: Yeah.
[indiscernible] .

Should we be assuming 5 million a quarter of amortization on your side, or will it be a lower number than that?

Sarah, on that one, I think the parties agreed to keep the terms of the contract confidential.

Q: Thank you very much.

A: Yeah.

As we've said in the past, we have certain contracts that go 15 years.

We even have some contracts that have gone to - that are going to 20 years because to the broadcaster, it's really an asset to have a long-term contract because it gives the broadcaster certainty of having the available distribution capability.
With regard to the first question in terms of broadcasters returning capacity, generally I haven't seen that over the many years.

The one exception, I think, and we've spoken about that a lot was the German analog, the German analog scenario, obviously when there was a move out of analog, so yeah, those broadcasters returned to that.
We will be seeing that now contracting very nicely back into the market.

So, overall, we don't see...
A: Maybe, Padraig, if we link it to the comments you made on fully protected backlog.

We are not sure whether that's the standard in our industry, which means that the backlog, the 7.5 million are contractually secured and the customer cannot step out of the contract.

And there is one exception Padraig was referring to that we were experiencing this together was Premiere and the Kersh Group went into bankruptcy, obviously Premiere was in a very shaky position and they wanted to survive and we agreed to a restructuring of the satellite capacity whereby we allowed them to use that capacity for a period and then increasing it over time and even going beyond what they had contracted because they went into the bankruptcy situation.

So, all in all, it was a very positive development for SES in terms of capacity needs from Premiere, now Sky Deutschland but at that time, we accepted that for a short period they would not need to contract the - to pay and to use for all the capacity contracted.
Q: Sorry, just a follow on then.

So, it's Padraig here.

So we - let's, first of all, deal with new business.
So during the course of 2014, we saw good traction in new business.
Some of the examples have been announced, the Pathfinder contract that was signed which is in the international markets.
There was also some WIN-T, very good North American contract signed.
Both of these contracts are multi-year contracts.
So it's a new way for doing business.
And so, when it comes to the - let's say the new business activity, this performed quite well during 2014.

The challenge that we face and on that one, we hope that we are bottoming out of that, but we still may have some pressure points in that in the first half of 2015 is more around the existing business and the renewals.
And so, overall, the business in the end of the year ended up pretty much as we guided in October.

We were down about 14% year-to-year, and we expect some growth this year, but we continue to remain somewhat cautious in all of this, because even though the new business trajectory looks nice, we still feel there's not the overall stability yet in the renewals and the ongoing business.
So on the first question regarding 4K, let's try to dig into one or two sort of points.
One is, are there conversations ongoing with the important broadcasters regarding transponder capacity that would be dedicated to 4K?
The answer is yes.
These conversations are ongoing.
Our expectation is that this would become mainstream in 2016.
Like on previous calls or conversations I've had in person, there are a number of elements that need to come into place.

The very good point here to note is that, once consumers are exposed to a 4K experience, the sort of the statement of intent to upgrade to transition and to purchase into that proposition is very strong.
So, it exists two-third, which is very good.
The other element of sort of the equation can't supply sort of meet demand.
Our view at the investor briefing back in June was that, we will start seeing this in 2016.
The standards are aligning.
There are still sort of incremental features that could come in the next six months to 12 months.
But we have today, the standard and the feature, to consider that the launch in 2016 is going to be there.
And what is also encouraging is that the pickup of 4K screen is moving much faster than what we have seen.

In fact with the - with the transition, when we were in the middle of a standard definition to high definition, the numbers that we are looking out is that in 2014, there was close to 12 million Ultra HD screens that were sold two year after launch.
And this is fast - much faster than HD.
In fact, it took six years for high-definition TV screens, which were launched in 1998 to reach similar sales levels.

And the last data point I want to share is, during our Investors Day, we had talked about the fact that by 2020, we estimate that there will be around 20 Ultra HD channels and a 100 million Ultra HD screens, if I just take the screens element.
And if I take the base of what was shipped and purchased in the 2014 year, without factoring any growth will be already closed to 90 million screens.

So, the elements are converging for a 2016 reality, which explains the first statement I've made that there are already conversations with important broadcasters of our transponders that will carry Ultra HD channels.
Q: That's great.
Thank you very much.
So, can I just clarify that the 90 million and the 100 million please that you said sorry, the 90 million screens was...

You're going to end up with a number closer to 85 million to 90 million.

Q: So, if Ultra HD screens remain 5% of total shipments then you'll reach the 85 million to 90 million by 2020?

Q: That's great.
Thank you.

A: And I do appreciate, David, that given these - the relation we have with SpaceX across all of multi-launches, there's going to be, I think, a very strong sort of convergence of interest to have this launch happening either at the end of Q2 or within the sort of the window of Q3.
Q: Okay.
A: Yes.
And on the second question, David, on the O3B position.
So first of all, on the risk - on an impairment, we don't see that.
I mean the business is commercially now doing very well.
The business is technically doing very well.

I think it's on the trajectory to actually deliver the results that both Karim and I have mentioned in which the COO also himself had mentioned, and that's even happening earlier, was foreseen before.
So all of that is going very, very good.
On the - your question with respect to the share of losses, on that one, we would continue to expect losses in 2017.
That would be normal.
I think that probably then looking into the period 2018.

And even then, when look to the EBIT and the retirement of debt to capital, all that's very attractive, because in parallel, with the type of spacecrafts we're launching and the hybrid spacecrafts, the cost per megahertz, or in the case of HTS, the cost per megabyte is also going down.
With respect to the wider question about looking out over 2014 to 2020, I think we will update next year our rolling forward three-year guidance.
I wouldn't really want to preempt that now.

What I can say is similar to what I think we said previously is that, when you look more holistically at the type of CapEx profile we have here and the dividend that we're paying, and we're prepared to 10% increase in the dividend this year, which is something we will stress test also going forward.

And when you look at all of that, and I said that previously, and you look where we are in the leverage, which is temporarily a little bit high because of the dollar, we see out over that period of 2018, 2019, the ability to generate overall financial headroom.

A: Yes.

When if look at the revenues, the revenues went up by 12%.
So you may look at this and say there is a - there is naturally the impact of operating and emerging markets, and this is reflective on this.

But the fact of the matter is because we're constructing, we're producing our programs much more cost efficiently, and in fact Martin, our CTO, during the Investor Day reported to the 20% to 30% cost improving our programs.
Our margins are being maintained if not improved.
If you look at the same comparable to peers in the industry, you're going to see that the ratio of revenue realization to channel count realization is much, much lower.
And we always said that the operational optimization is a number one target for us.
And for us to sort of have the right operating model in the emerging market is going to be the sort of the secret sauce for us to succeed there and retain the margin.
So imperative, we've been able to do that over the next - over the past three years, and certainly that is the intent over the next three years.

And so as long as we're growing revenues and our utilization rate at a commensurate manner, that is going to be the most efficient way of serving the interests of the company, of the shareholders.
So could we expect it to be at 80%?
That is certainly part of our five-year plan.

When it comes to Latin America, the emphasis for us is very particular applications, targeting very particular markets.

So if I take the example of SES-14 and SES-15, these two programs on the one hand, particularly SES-14 is addressing a sort of very important market from a video standpoint, but equally important is serving along with SES-15 is very important platform when it comes to mobility with an emphasis on aeronautical mobility.

Which is why, from our perspective, when we initiated our investment in O3B, that solution was the more efficient solution, both from a sort of an end service experience to the customer and also from a cost efficiency standpoint since it's being offered at a much more favorable return than traditional point-to-point sort of capacity over geo-based satellites.

Q: And Karim, can I come back to one point you made, I'm not sure I understood, with regards to the design life of the new satellites, am I right to understand about what you said is that the base you're modeling to get to your 10% IRR or more on a 10-year lifetime?

A: Yes.
A: Our experience with almost all our satellites is they would extend that lifetime even more, so our expectation is more pronounced with all electrical propulsions.

A: Thanks very much, Padraig.

Could I ask you, when you take the microphone, please identify yourselves and your organization?
Giles?
Q: Okay.
There we go.
It's Giles from Jefferies.
I have three questions, please.

Starting with the whole fraca this past week between Gogo and American Airlines that made you consider the timing and implications with downstream consolidation and the in-flight connectivity market, be interested to hear your perspective on consolidation and also your thoughts on any potential revenue risks.
So for example, in the past year, you've signed capacity with all three, Panasonic, Gogo and Global Eagle, as you highlighted earlier.
So capacity on SES-14 and SES-15 over the Americas, if three suddenly becomes one and pricing power goes up with the last man standing, what's your exposure there?

Secondly, ViaSat-3, we're beginning to learn more and more details around ViaSat-3 and some of the numbers coming out on the cost per bit or throughput are eyewatering, and all else being equal, should have the incumbents worried.
I'm using deliberately confrontational language.
Be interested to hear your perspective on that looming infrastructure competition risk and actually how shrewd you think Eutelsat have been by getting in to divert them in Europe?

And then, lastly, on Canal, in France, some may be worried around the size of the challenge Vivendi have in turning that business around much of the rhetoric out of Vivendi is being about redesigning and repackaging the entire customer experience.
I'd be interested to hear what risks you see associated with that turnaround and indeed whether you're part of the solution or part of the problem?
That was it.
A: Thank you.
So - am I fine here?
Yeah?
Thank you.
So on the first question, obviously, we're not in a position to have a view or speculate on consolidation in the IFC, IT industry.
But here is how the business model works.
As more and more airplanes are connected, the demand for increased connectivity on satellite will continue to go up, i.e., you pretty have a linear relation between these two.
So irrespective of whether you have one or three players, you still need that capacity.

In fact, if you end with the scenario where there is, let's say, consolidation and region, what have you, you may have a thesis that this consolidation will probably enable the development at a faster pace of certain applications, and therefore, it will reflect very positive in terms of demand on our side.
It's very different from consolidation in video neighborhoods where you have two operators.
They - both of them serving on two different satellites, if they come together, there's an expression where which neighborhood do you keep and which neighborhood do you sort of move away from.
So irrespective of how it plays out, this is going to be very accretive to our business.
When it comes to sort of what is being discussed and presented in the industry, so you've mentioned one program and there are many other programs.
We're taking a view that is very specific to SES, i.e., we believe that the technology of the future should be able to do three things.
One is provide the wide beam and the high-throughput beams.
These two need to work together.
One does not replace the other.
Secondly, you need to be able to answer the question of latency.
As more and more - I mean we're moving increasingly into a world of cloud-based application.
This is what 5G talks about.
This is what we do on most of our devices, as increasingly moving to cloud-based applications, latency becomes an important issue.
And unless you have a way to address it, you're sort of - there's a very sizeable part of the market that you cannot sort of serve in a way that is depreciated.
And so, when you bring these three capability together, you have a formidable service offering.
Our view is when it comes to wide beam coverage, with an existing fleet and the replacement programs we already have, we pretty much have the right coverage and the right assets.
The forward-looking investment we're going to make are going to be in two-folds.
One is in high-throughput on GEO satellites.
And we'll continue to work with a view that these will be hybrid satellites, because you can scale this very, very quickly.
The challenge with the different programs that were announced not just recently, but over the past few years, is that you build them and it's a fixed program.
And if there is an evolution in the technology, you're sort of hostage of the first generation or the second generation.

And you don't have the ability to scale, which is why we chose to have a hybrid model, because you can keep on scaling and leveraging the best technology going forward, but also making sure that it's backward compatible, so this is one.

And two, you work on a fleet where scaling up from a price standpoint and from a technology standpoint is much more achievable which is O3b, because you can build these literally a [indiscernible], put them sort of the industrial model is very different.
And we think this is quite unique to us.

And last but not least, when it comes to Canal, and most of the pay TV operators, I think there is an evolution of the thought process as to what is going to be the video experience of the future and how they're going to differentiate.

And in the mature market, that sort of experience may well be sort of aligning with our thesis of a truly hybrid experience, which is why I've allowed myself to comment in the case of the Sky Q Silver Box that this model brings the best of the two worlds.

And even now, our conversations - allow me to move beyond Canal specific, even in our conversation as part of the 5G-PPP, since this was a recent conversation we've had, in fact, as soon as this week, on a panel where I participated with the telcos and the equipment manufacturers, so the likes of Ericsson and Nokia and ZTE.
There is a converging view now that in the video-centric data demanding world, the satellite solution would need to be integrated.
And that was the common view.
So this was not the satellite view being discussed in a satellite-only conversation.
This was in conversation with the telco players whether it's on the industrial side or on the service operator side.

And so, beyond the Canal specific question, we believe on the mature market where you have the benefit of fixed, wireless and space-based technologies, these things will come together to create the most cost efficient experience.
Well, in the case of Canal, all our agreements and many of these agreements continue to be locked in last year, go until beyond the end of this decade, we worked with them very closely.
I think in the video industry, you'll always see sort of development in one direction or the others.

I mean we've seen comparable developments in the case of other pay TV operators we served in recent years, and I think in some shape or form, the business will grow and we'll continue to serve it, so.

And after lengthy discussions and reviews and as we were developing our programs, the best fit was really between what they were bringing to the table and the capacity that we had.
So there is no relation whatsoever with - I mean it's the hypothesis, but we don't believe.
I mean the timings didn't - certainly they didn't happen at the same time.
And when it comes to O3b, I'm happy to offer and respectfully, the answer is no.
Our optionality to take control of O3b continues to prevail.
In fact, if I can reiterate what I've said, now that optionality, the path of that optionality has been cleared.
So it's just a matter of how do we want to execute it.
And whether this optionality is a 50% point or 100% remains on the table.
Nothing has been eliminated.
A: [indiscernible], please.
Q: [indiscernible].
A: Thank you.
So on the first question, you're sort of - the model that you've outlined is spot on, i.e.
our ability to achieve very high growth rates from SD or transition from SD to HD is allowing us also to manage, at the same time, transition from MPEG-2 to MPEG-4, and we continue to be successful.
I mean for you to appreciate, we are probably the most advanced in terms of this transition.
60% already has been migrated to MPEG-4.
But given also the high growth in the number of channels that we've achieved particularly in HD, we've mitigated that and we delivered a reported growth and as well as growth on constant FX.
So that is exactly the model that we will continue to work on.
And if you remember, I've mentioned this back in 2014, and I continue to believe that that's the way to go.

We should, in fact, encourage this passage from one generation to the other, because if anything, it's democratizing a much better experience to everyone which will play out, in the long term, much more favorably to the satellite industry.
To the questions on LEOs, most of the LEOs that have been announced have been announced in the consumer broadband business.
So I think the question will be, well, how this will impact the consumer broadband business that is being served today via GEO satellites.
And we took a view within SES that we can only have laser-focus and commitment to four market verticals and consumer broadband is not part of our coverage.
And last but not least, your point is very relevant in terms of SES-9 and our clients.
We've managed this very well with them.
They saw all our contracts are geared in a manner that as we bring these clients online during the second half of this year, we remain perfectly within the framework of our agreements with them.
So we should continue to expect that quickly into the period post the operationalization of the satellite, we'll reach the 65% utilization level.
A: Do we have any questions online?
Yes.
